titleStmt.title: Sr Martin Mar-all, or, The feign'd innocence a comedy, as it was acted at His Highnesse the Duke of York's Theatre.
titleStmt.author: Dryden, John, 1631-1700.
Molière, 1622-1673. Etourdi.
Newcastle, William Cavendish, Duke of, 1592-1676.
Quinault, Philippe, 1635-1688. Amant indiscret.

notesStmt.note: Adapted by Dryden from the Duke of Newcastle's translation of Molière's "L'étourdi" and Quinault's "L'amant indiscret".
Differs from Wing D2360 (reel 688:5) only in the Epilogue, which here has a shorter text and is captioned: "Epilogue".
Reproduction of original in Duke University Library.

div.p: Sr Martin Mar-all, OR, THE Feignd Innocence: A COMEDY. As it was Acted at His HIGHNESSE the DUKE of YORK'S THEATRE.
LONDON, Printed for H. Herringman, at the Sign of the Blew Anchor in the Lower Walk of the New Exchange. 1608.

lg.l: FOols, which each man meets in his Dish each day,
Are yet the great Regalio's of a Play;
In which to Poets you but just appear,
To prize that highest which cost them so dear:
Fops in the Town more easily will pass;
One story makes a statutable Ass,
But such in Plays must be much thicker sown,
Like yolks of Eggs, a dozen beat to one.
Observing Poets all their walks invade,
As men watch Woodcocks gliding through a Glade:
And when they have enough for Comedy,
They stow their several Bodies in a Pye:
The Poet's but the Cook to fashion it,
For, Gallants, you your selves have found the wit.
To bid you welcome would your bounty wrong,
None welcome those who bring their Chear along.

div.head: THE Feignd Innocence: OR Sir MARTIN MARRALL.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: WHere the Devil is this Master of mine? he is ever out of the way when he should do himself good. This 'tis to serve a Coxcomb, one that has no more brains than just those I carry for him. Well! of all Fopps commend me to him for the greatest; he's so opinion'd of his own Abilities, that he is ever designing somewhat, and yet he sows his Stratagems so shallow, that every Daw can pick'em up: from a plotting Fool the Lord deliver me. Here he comes, O! it seems his Cousin's with him, then it is not so bad as I imagin'd.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Martin Marral, Lady Dupe.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: I think 'twas well contriv'd for your access to lodge her in the same house with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: 'Tis pretty well I must confess.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Had he plotted it himself, it had been admirable

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: For when her Father Moody writ to me to take him Lodgings, I so order'd it, the choice seem'd his, not mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I have hit of a thing my self sometimes, when wiser Heads have miss'd it— But that might be meer luck.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: Fortune does more than Wisdom.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: Nay, for that you shall excuse me;
I will not value any mans Fortune at a rush,
Except he have Wit and Parts to bear him out.
But when do you expect 'em?

sp.speaker: La Dupe.
sp.l: This Tide will bring them from Gravesend.
You had best let your man go as from me,
And wait them at the Stairs in Durham-yard.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: Lord, Cousin, what a do is here with your Counsel!
As though I could not have thought of that my self.
I could find in my heart not to send him now— stay a little
— I could soon find out some other way.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: A minute's stay may lose your business.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Well, go then,— but you must grant, if he had stay'd, I could have found a better way,— you grant it.

sp.speaker: La Dupe.
sp.l: For once I will not stand with you.—
'Tis a sweet Gentlewoman this Mrs. Millisent, if you can get her.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Let me alone for plotting.

sp.speaker: La Dupe.
sp.l: But by your favour, Sir, 'tis not so easie,
Her Father has already promis'd her:
And the young Gentleman comes up with 'em:
I partly know the man,— but the old Squire is humoursome,
He's stout, and plain in speech and in behaviour;
He loves none of the fine Town-tricks of breeding,
But stands up for the old Elizabeth way in all things.
This we must work upon.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Sure! you think you have to deal with a Fool, Cousin?

sp.speaker: La Dupe.
sp.p: O my dear Neice, I have some business with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: Well, Madam, I'le take one turn here i'th Piazza's;
A thousand things are hammering in this head;
'Tis a fruitful Noddle, though I say it.

sp.speaker: La Dupe.
sp.p: Go thy wayes for a most conceited Fool.— But to our business, Cousin: you are young, but I am old, and have had all the Love-experience that a discreet Lady ought to have; and therefore let me instruct you about the Love this rich Lord makes to you.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: You know, Madam, he's Marry'd, so that we cannot work upon that ground of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: La Dupe.
sp.p: But there are advantages enough for you, if you will be wise and follow my advice.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Madam, my Friends left me to your care, therefore I will wholly follow your Counsel with secrecy and obedience.

sp.speaker: La Dupe.
sp.p: Sweet-heare, it shall be the better for you another day: well then, this Lord that pretends to you is crafty and false, as most men are, especially in Love;— therefore we must be subtle to meet with all his Plots, and have Countermines against his Workes to blow him up.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: As how, Madam?

sp.speaker: La Dupe.
sp.p: Why, Girl, hee'l make fierce Love to you, but you must not suffer him to ruffle you, or steal a kiss: but you must weep and sigh, and say you'l tell me on't, and that you will not be us'd so; and play the innocent just like a Child, and seem ignorant of all.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I warrant you 'Ile be very ignorant, Madam.

sp.speaker: La Dupe.
sp.p: And be sure when he has tows'd you, not to appear at Supper that night, that you may fright him.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: No, Madam.

sp.speaker: La Dupe.
sp.p: That he may think you have told me.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: And keep your Chamber, and say your head akes:

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: O, most extreamly, Madam.

sp.speaker: La Dupe.
sp.p: And lock the door, and admit of no night-visits: at Supper I'l ask where's my Cousin, and being told you are not well, I'l start from the Table to visit you, desiring his Lordship not to incommode himself; for I will presently wait on him agen.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: But how, when you are return'd, Madam?

sp.speaker: La Dupe.
sp.p: Then somewhat discompos'd, I'l say, I doubt the Meazles or Small-pox will seize on you, and then the Girl is spoil'd; saying, Poor thing, her Portion is her Beauty and her Vertue; and often send to see how you do, by whispers in my Servants ears, and have those whispers of your health return'd to mine: if his Lordship thereupon askes how you do, I will pretend it was some other thing.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Right, Madam, for that will bring him further in suspence.

sp.speaker: La Dupe.
sp.p: A hopeful Girl! Then will I eate nothing that night, feigning my grief for you; but keep his Lordship Company at Meal, and seem to strive to put my passion off, yet shew it still by small mistakes.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: And broken Sentences.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: A dainty Girl! and after Supper visit you again, with promise to return strait to his Lordship: but after I am gone send an Excuse, that I have given you a Cordial, and mean to watch that night in person with you.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: His Lordship then will find the Prologue of his trouble, doubting I have told you of his ruffling.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: And more than that, fearing his Father should know of it, and his Wife, who is a Termagant Lady: but when he finds the Coast is clear, and his late ruffling known to none but you, he will be drunk with joy.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Finding my simple Innocence, which will inflame him more.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: Then what the Lyon's skin has fail'd him in, the Foxes subtlety must next supply, and that is just, Sweet-heart, as I would have it; for crafty Folks treaties are their advantage: especially when his passion must be satisfi'd at any rate, and you keep shop to set the price of Love: so now you see the Market is your own.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Truly, Madam, this is very rational; and by the blessing of Heav'n upon my poor endeavours, I do not doubt to play my part.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: My blessing and my pray'rs go along with thee.
sp.stage: Enter Sir John Swallow. Mrs. Millesent, and Rose her Maid.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I believe, Madam, here is the young Heiress you expect, and with her he who is to marry her.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: Howe're I am Sir Martins Friend, I must not seem his Enemy.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Madam, this fair young Lady begs the honour to be known to you.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: My Father made me hope it, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: Sweet Lady, I believe you have brought all the Freshness of the Country up to Town with you.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: I came up, Madam, as we Country-Gentlewomen use, at an Easter-Term, to the destruction of Tarts and Cheese-cakes, to see a New Play, buy a new Gown, take a Turn in the Park, and so down agen to sleep with my Fore-fathers.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Rather, Madam, you are come up to the breaking of many a poor Heart, that like mine will languish for you.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I doubt, Madam, you are indispos'd with your Voyage; will you please to see the Lodgings your Father has provided for you?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: To wait upon you, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: This is the door,— there is a Gentleman will wait you immediately in your Lodging, if he might presume on your Commands.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: You mean Sir Martin Marrall: I am glad he has entrusted his passion with so discreet a person.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: Sir John, let me intreat you to stay here, that my Father may have intelligence where to find us.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I shall obey you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Sir Martin Marrall! most happily encounter'd! how long have you been come to Town?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Some three dayes since, or thereabouts: but I thank God I am very weary on't already.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter, man?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: My villainous old luck still follows me in gaming, I never throw the Dice out of my hand, but my Gold goes after 'em: if I go to Picquet, though it be but with a Novice in't, he will picque and repicque, and Capot me twenty times together: and which most mads me, I lose all my Sets when I want but one of up.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: The pleasure of play is lost, when one loses at that unreasonable rate.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: But I have sworn not to touch either Cards or Dice this half year.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: The Oaths of losing Gamesters are most minded; they foreswear play as an angry Servant does his Mistress, because he loves her but too well.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: But I am now taken up with thoughts of another nature; I am in love, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
That's the worst Game you could have play'd at, scarce one Woman in an hundred will play with you upon the
Square: you venture at more uncertainty than at a Lottery: for you set your heart to a whole Sex of Blanks. But is your Mistress Widow, Wife, or Maid?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: I can assure you, Sir, mine is a Maid;
The Heiress of a wealthy Family,
Fair to a Miracle.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Does she accept your service?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I am the only person in her favour.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Is she of Town or Country?

sp.speaker: Warn. aside.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: She is of Kent, near Canterbury.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: What does he mean? this is his Rival—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Near Canterbury say you? I have a small Estate lies thereabouts, and more concernments than one besides.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: I'l tell you then, being at Canterbury;
It was my Fortune once in the Cathedral Church—

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir, to intrust this man with your Affair thus?—

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Trust him? why, he's a friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: No matter for that; hark you a Word Sir.—

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Prethee leave fooling:— and as I was saying— I was in the Church when I first saw this fair one.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Her Name, Sir, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake, Sir, have a care?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Thou art such a Coxcomb.— Her name's Millisent.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Now, the Pox take you Sir, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Millisent say you? that's the name of my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Lord! what luck is that now! well Sir, it happen'd, one of her Gloves fell down, I stoop'd to take it up; And in the stooping made her a Complement.—

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: The Devil cannot hold him, now will this thick-skull'd Master of mine tell the whole story to his Rival—

sp.speaker: Sir. Mart.
sp.p: You'l say, 'twas strange Sir; but at the first glance we cast on one another, both our hearts leap'd within us, our Souls met at our Eyes, and with a tickling kind of pain slid to each others breast, and in one moment setled as close and warm, as if they long had been acquainted with their lodging. I follow'd her somewhat at a distance, because her Father was with her.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Yet hold Sir——

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Sawcy Rascal, avoid my sight; Must you tutor me? So Sir, not to trouble you, I enquir'd out her Father's House, without whose knowledge I did Court the Daughter, and both then and often since coming to Canterbury, I receiv'd many proofs of her kindness to me.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: You had best tell him too, that I am acquainted with her Maid, and manage your love under-hand with her.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Well remember'd i'faith, I thank thee for that, I had forgot it I protest! my Valet de Chambre, whom you see here with me, grows me acquainted with her Woman—

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: O the Devil.—

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: In fine Sir, this Maid being much in her Mistresses favour, so well sollicited my Cause, that in fine I gain'd from fair Mistress Millisent an assurance of her kindness, and an ingagement to marry none but me.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: 'Tis very well! you've made a fair discovery!—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: A most pleasant Relation I assure you: you are a happy man Sir! but, What occasion brought you now to London?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: That was in expectation to meet my Mistress here; she writ me word from Canterbury, she and her Father shortly would be here.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: She and her Father, said you Sir?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Tell him Sir, for Heavens sake tell him all—

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: So I will Sir, without your bidding: her Father and she are come up already, that's the truth on't, and are to lodge by my Contrivance in you House; the Master of which is a cunning Rascal as any in Town— him I have made my own, for I lodge there.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: You do ill, Sir, to speak so scandalously of my Landlord.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Peace, or I'l break your Fool's head,— So that by his means I shall have free egress and regress when I please Sir— without her Fathers knowledge.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: I am out of patience to hear this.—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Methinks you might do well, Sir, to speak openly to her Father.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Thank you for that i'faith, in speaking to old Moody I may soon spoil all.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: So now he has told her Father's name, 'tis past recovery.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Is her Fathers name Moody say you?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Is he of your acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Yes Sir, I know him for a man
Who is too wise for you to over-reach;
I am certain he will never marry his Daughter
To you.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: Why, there's the jest on't:
He shall never know it: 'tis but your
Keeping of my Counsel; I'le do as much for you mun—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: No Sir, I'le give you better; trouble not your self about this Lady; her affections are otherwise engaged to my knowledge— hark in your Ear— her Father hates a Gamester like a Devil: I'le keep your Counsel for that too.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Nay but this is not all dear Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: This is all I assure you: only I will make bold
To seek your Mistress out another Lodging—

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Your Affairs are now put into an excellent posture, Thank your incomparable discretion— this was a Stratagem my shallow wit could ne're have reach'd, to make a Confident of my Rival.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I hope thou art not in earnest man! is he my Rival?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: 'Slife he has not found it out all this while! well
Sir for a quick apprehension let you alone.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: How the Devil cam'st thou to know ont? and
Why the Devil didst thou not tell me ont?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: To the first of your Devil's I answer, her Maid Rose told me on't: to the second I wish a thousand Devils take him that would not hear me.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: O unparallell'd Misfortune!

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p:
O unparrellell'd ignorance! why he left her Father at the water-side, while he lead the Daughter to her Lodging, whither I directed him; so that if you had not laboured to the contrary, Fortune had plac'd you in the same House with your Mistress, without the least suspicion of your Rival or of her Father:
but, 'tis well, you have satisfi'd your talkative humour: I hope you have some new project of your own to set all right agen: for my part I confess all my designs, for you are wholly ruin'd; the very foundations of 'em are blown up.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Prethee insult not over the Destiny of a poor undone Lover, I am punish'd enough for my indiscretion in my despair, and have nothing to hope for now but death.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Death is a Bug-word, things are not brought to that extremity, I'le cast about to save all yet.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: O, Sir Martin! yonder has been such a stir within, Sir John, I fear, smoaks your design, and by all means would have the old man remove his Lodging; pray God your man has not play'd false.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Like enough I have: I am Coxcomb sufficient to do it, my Master knows that none but such a great Calf as I could have done it, such an over-grown Ass, a self-conceited Ideot as I.—

sp.speaker: Sir. Mart.
sp.p: Nay, Warner,—

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let me alone:— what is it to you if I rail upon my self? now could I break my own Loggar-head.

sp.speaker: Sir. Mart.
sp.p: Nay, sweet Warner.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: What a good Master have I, and I to ruine him: O Beast!—

sp.speaker: La Dupe.
sp.p: Not to discourage you wholly, Sir Martin, this storm is partly over.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: As how, dear Cousin.

sp.speaker: La D.
sp.p: When I heard Sir John complain of the Landlord, I took the first hint of it, and joyn'd with him, saying, if she were such an one, I would have nothing to do with him: in short I ratled him so well, that Sir John was the first who did desire they might be lodg'd with me, not knowing that I was your Kinswoman.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Pox on't, now I think on't, I could have found out this my self.—

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Are you there agen, Sir?— now as I have a Soul—

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Mum, good Warner, I did but forget my self a little, I leave my self wholly to you, and my Cousin; get but my Mistress for me and claim what e'r reward you can desire.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Hope of reward will diligence beget,
Find you the Money, and I'l find the wit.

sp.stage: Enter Lady Dupe, and Mrs. Christian.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: IT hapned Madam, just as you said it would,
But was he so concern'd for my feign'd sickness?

sp.speaker: La. D.
sp.p: So much that Moody and his Daughter, our new Guests, took notice of the trouble, but the Cause was kept too close for Strangers to divine.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Heav'n grant he be but deep enough in love, and then—

sp.speaker: La. D.
sp.l: And then thou shalt distil him into Gold my Girl.
Yonder he comes, I'l not be seen:— you know
Your Lesson, Child.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Pretty Mistress Christian,
How glad am I to meet you thus alone!

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: O the Father! what will become of me now?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: No harm I warrant you, but why are you so fraid?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: A poor weak innocent Creature as I am, Heav'n of his mercy, how I quake and tremble! I have not yet claw'd off your last ill usage, and now I feel my old fit come again, my Ears tingle already, and my back shuts and opens; I, just so it began before.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Nay, my sweet Mistress, be not so unjust
To suspect any new attempt:
I am too penitent for my last fault,
So soon to sin agen.—
I hope you did not tell it to your Aunt.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: The more Fool I, I did not.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: You never shal repent your goodness to me,
But may not I presume there was some little
Kindness in it, which mov'd you to conceal my
Crime?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Methought I would not have mine Aunt angry with you for all this earthly good;
But yet I'l never be alone with you agen.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Pretty Innocence! let me sit nearer to you:
You do not understand what love I bear you.
I vow it is so pure——
My Soul's not sully'd with one spot of sin:
Were you a Sister or a Daughter to me,
With a more holy Flame I could not burn.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Nay, now you speak high words— I cannot understand you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: The business of my life shall be but how to make your Fortune, and my care and study to advance and see you settled in the World.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I humbly thank your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Thus I would sacrifice my Life and Fortunes,
And in return you cruelly destroy me.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I never meant you any harm, not I.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Then what does this white Enemy so near me?
Sure 'tis your Champion, and you arm it thus to bid defiance to me.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Nay, fye my Lord, in faith you are to blame.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: But I am for fair Wars, an Enemy must first be search'd for privy Armour e'r we do ingage.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: What does your Lordship mean?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: I fear you bear some Spells and Charms about you,
And, Madam, that's against the Laws of Arms.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: My Aunt charg'd me not to pull off my Glove for fear of Sun-burning my hand.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: She did well to keep it from your eyes, but I will thus preserve it.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Why do you crush it so? nay, now you hurt me, nay— if you squeeze it ne'r so hard— there's nothing to come out on't— fye— is this loving one— What makes you take your breath so short?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: The Devil take me if I can answer her a word,
All my Sences are quite imploy'd another way.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Ne'r stir, my Lord, I must cry out—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
Then I must stop your mouth— this Ruby for a Kiss—
that is but one Ruby for another.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: This is worse and worse.

sp.speaker: Lady within.
sp.l: Why Neece, where are you Neece?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Pox of her old mouldy Chops.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Do you hear, my Aunt calls? I shall be hang'd for staying with you— let me go my Lord.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: D. My Lord, Heaven bless me, what makes your Lordship here?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I was just wishing for you Madam, your Neece and I have been so laughing at the blunt humour of your Country-Gentleman,— I must go pass an hour with him.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: You made a little too much haste;
I was just exchanging a Kiss for a Ruby.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: No harm done; it will make him come on the faster:
Never sull-gorge an Hawk you mean to fly:
The next will be a Neck-lace of Pearl I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: But what must I do next?

sp.speaker: La Dupe.
sp.l: Tell him I grew suspicious, and examin'd you
Whether he made not Love; which you deny'd.
Then tell him how my Maids and Daughters watch you;
So that you tremble when you see his Lordship.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: And that your Daughters are so envious, that they would raise a false report to ruine me.

sp.speaker: La. D.
sp.l: Therefore you desire his Lordship,
As he loves you, of which you are confident,
Hence-forward to forbear his Visits to you.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: But how if he should take me at my Word?

sp.speaker: La. D.
sp.p: Why, if the worst come to the worst, he leaves you an honest woman, and there's an end on't: but fear not that, hold out his messages, and then he'll write, and that is it my Bird which you must drive it to: then all his Letters will be such Extacies, such Vows and Promises, which you must answer short and simply, yet still ply out of 'em your advantages.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: But, Madam! he's i'th house, he will not write.

sp.speaker: La. D.
sp.p:
You Fool— he'll write from the next Chamber to you. And rather than fail, send his Page-Post with it upon a Hobby-horse:— then grant a Meeting, but tell me of it, and I'le I revent
him by my being there, he'l curse me, but I care not.
When you are alone, he'l urge his lust, which answer you with sorn and anger.——

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: As thus an't please you, Madam?
What? Does he think I will be damn'd for him?
Defame my Family, ruine my Name,
To satisfie his pleasure?

sp.speaker: La Dupe.
sp.l: Then he will be prophane in's Arguments,
Urge Natures Laws to you.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: By'r Lady, and those are shrewd Arguments;
But I am resolved I'l stop my Ears.

sp.speaker: La Dupe.
sp.l: Then when he sees no other thing will move you,
He'l sign a portion to you before hand:
Take hold of that, and then of what you will.
sp.stage: Enter Sir John, Mrs. Millisent, and Rose.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Now fair Mrs. Millisent, you see your Chamber, Your Father will be busie a few minutes, and in the mean time permits me the happiness to wait on you.—

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Methinks you might have chose us better Lodgings,
This house is full; the other we saw first, was more convenient.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: For you perhaps, but not for me:
You might have met a Lover there, but I a Rival.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: What Rival?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: You know, Sir Martin, I need not name it to you.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: I know more men besides him.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But you love none besides him: Can you deny your affection to him?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: You have vex'd me so, I will not satisfie you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Then I perceive I am not likely to be so much oblig'd to you as I was to him.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: This is Romance,—— I'l not believe a word on't.—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: That's as you please: however 'tis believ'd,
His wit will not much credit your choice.
Madam, do justice to us both; pay his ingratitude and folly with your scorn; my service with your Love.

By this time your Father stayes for me: I shall be discreet enough
to keep this fault of yours from him;
The Lawyers wait for us to draw your Joynture:
And I would beg your pardon for my absence,
But that my Crime is punish'd in it self.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Could I suspect this usage from a favour'd Servant!

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: First hear Sir Martin e're you quite condemn him;
Consider 'tis a Rival who accus'd him.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Speak not a word in his behalf:—
Methought too, Sir John call'd him Fool.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Indeed he has a rare way of acting a Fool, and does it so naturally, it can be scarce distinguish'd.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Nay, he has wit enough, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: How blind Love is!

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: How now, what's his business?
I wonder after such a Crime,
If his Master has the face to send him to me.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: How durst you venture hither?
If either Sir John or my old Master see you.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.l: Pish! they are both gone out.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: They went but to the next street; ten to one but they return and catch you here.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.l: Twenty to one I am gone before, and save'um a labour.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: What says that Fellow to you? what business can he have here?

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: Lord, that your Ladiship should ask that question, Knowing whom I serve!

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: I'le hear nothing from your Master.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: Never breathe, but this anger becomes your Ladiship most admirably; but though you'l hear nothing from him, I hope I may speak a word or two to you from my self, Madam.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: 'T was a sweet Prank your Master play'd us: a Lady's well helpt up that trusts her Honour in such a persons hands: to tell all so,— and to his Rival too.
Excuse him if thou canst.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: How the Devil should I excuse him? thou knowest he is the greatest Fop in Nature—

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: But my Lady does not know it; if she did—

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: I'le have no whispering.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Alas, Madam, I have not the confidence to speak out,
Unless you can take mercy on me.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: For telling Sir John you lov'd my Master, Madam.
But sure I little thought he was his Rival.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: The witty Rogue has taken't on himself.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Your Master then is innocent.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Why, could your Ladyship suspect him guilty?
Pray tell me, do you think him
Ungrateful, or a fool?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: I think him neither.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Take it from me, you see not the depth of him.
But when he knows what thoughts you harbour of him,
As I am faithful, and must tell him,—
I wish he does not take some pet, and leave you.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Thou art not mad I hope, to tell him on't;
If thou dost, I'le be sworn, I'le forswear it to him.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Upon condition then you'l pardon me,
I'le see what I can do to hold my tongue.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: This Evening in S. Jame's Park I'le meet him.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: He shall not fail you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: Some body knocks— Oh Madam, what shall we do!
'Tis Sir John, I hear his voice.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Step quickly behind that Door,
To them Sir John.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: You've made a quick dispatch, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: We have done nothing, Madam, our Man of Law was not within,—— but I must look some Writings.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Where are they laid?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: In the Portmanteau in the Drawing-room.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Pray stay a little, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Warn. at the Door.
sp.p: He must pass just by me; and if he sees me, I am but a dead man.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Why are you thus concern'd? why do you hold me?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Only a word or two I have to tell you.
'Tis of importance to you.—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Give me leave.——

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: I must not before I discover the Plot to you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: What Plot?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Sir Martins Servant, like a Rogue, comes hither
To tempt me from his Master, to have met him.

sp.speaker: Warn. at the Door.
sp.p: Now would I had a good Bag of Gun-powder at my Breech to ram me into some hole.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: for my part I was so startled at the Message,
That I shall scarcely be my self these two dayes.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Oh that I had the Rascal! I would teach him
To come upon such Errands.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Oh for a gentle Composition now!
An Arm or Leg I would give willingly.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: What Answer did you make the Villain?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: I over-reach'd him clearly, by a Promise
Of an appointment of a place I nam'd,
Where I ne'r meant to come: but would have had
The pleasure first to tell you how I serv'd him.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: And then to chide your mean suspicion of me,
Indeed I wonder'd you should love a Fool.
But where did you appoint to meet him?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: In Grayes-Inn Walks.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: By this Light, she has put the change upon him!
O sweet Woman-kind, how I love thee for that heavenly gift of lying!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: For this evening I will be his Mistress;
He shall meet another Penelope then he suspects.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: But stay not long away.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: You over-joy me, Madam.

sp.speaker: Warn. entring.
sp.l: Is he gone, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: As far as Grayes-Inn Walks: now I have time
To walk the other way, and see thy Master.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.l: Rather let him come hither: I have laid
A Plot shall send his Rival far enough from watching him e'r long.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Art thou in earnest?

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: 'Tis so design'd, Fate cannot hinder it.
Our Landlord where we lie, vex'd that his Lodgings should be so left by Sir John, is resolv'd to be reveng'd, and I have found the way.
You'l see th' effect on't presently.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: O Heavens! the door opens agen, and Sir John is return'd once more.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Half my business was forgot; you did not tell me when you were to meet him. Ho! What makes this Rascal here?

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: 'Tis well you're come, Sir, else I must have left untold a Message I have for you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Well, What's your business, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.l: We must be private first; 'Tis only for your ear.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: I shall admire his wit, if in this plunge he can get off.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.l: I came hither, Sir, by my Masters order.—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: I'l reward you for it, Sirrah, immediately.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: When you know all, I shall deserve it, Sir;

I came to sound the Vertue of your Mistress; which I have done so cunningly, I have at last obtain'd the promise of a meeting. But my good Master, whom I must confess more generous than wise, knowing you had a passion for her, is resolv'd to quit: And, Sir, that you may see how much he loves you, sent me in private to advise you still to have an eye upon her actions.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Take this Diamond for thy good news;
And give thy Master my acknowledgments:

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Thus the World goes, my Masters, he that will cozen you, commonly gets your good will into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Madam, I am now satisfi'd of all sides; first of your truth, then of Sir Martins friendship.
In short, I find you two cheated each other,
Both to be true to me.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Warner is got off as I would wish, and the Knight over-reach'd.
sp.stage: Enter to them the Landlord disguis'd like a Carrier.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: How now! What would this Carrier have?

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: This is our Landlord whom I told you of; but keep your Countenance.—

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: I was looking here-away for one Sir John Swallow; they told me I might hear news of him in this House.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Friend, I am the man: What have you to say to me?

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.l: Nay, 'Faith Sir, I am not so good a Schollard to say much,
But I have a Letter for you in my Pouch:
There's plaguy news in't, I can tell you that.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: From whom is your Letter?

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.l: From your old Uncle Anthony.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Give me your Letter quickly.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.l: Nay, soft and fair goes far.— Hold you, hold you.
It is not in this Pocket.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Search in the other then; I stand on Thorns.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: I think I feel it now, this should be who.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Pluck it out then.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: I'l puck out my Spectacles and see first.
To Mr. Paul Grimbard— Apprentice to—
No, that's not for you, Sir,— that's for the Son of the Brother of the Nephew of the Cousin of my Gossip Dobson.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Prithee dispatch; do'st thou not know the Contents on't?

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.l: Yes, as well as I do my Pater Noster.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Well, What's the business on't?

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Nay, no great business; 'tis but only that your Worships Father's dead.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: My loss is beyond expression! how dy'd he?

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.l: He went to bed as well to see to as any man in England,
And when he awaken'd the next morning.—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.l: He found himself stark dead.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Well, I must of necessity take orders for my Father's Funeral, and my estate; Heaven knows with what regret I leave you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: But are you in such haste, Sir? I see you take all occasions to be from me.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Dear Madam, say not so, a few days will, I hope, return me to you.
Noble Sir Martin, the welcomest man alive!
Let me embrace my Friend.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: How untowardly he returns the salute! Warner will be found out.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Well friend! you have oblig'd me to you eternally.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: How have I oblig'd you, Sir? I would have you to know I scorn your words; and I would I were hang'd, if it be not the farthest of my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: O cunning Youth, he acts the Fool most naturally.
Were we alone, how would we laugh together?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: This is a double generosity,
To do me favours and conceal 'um from me;
But honest Warner here has told me all.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: What has the Rascal told you?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Your plot to try my Mistress for me— you understand me, concerning your appointment.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Sir, I desire to speak in private with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: This impertinent Rascal, when I am most busie, I am ever troubled with him.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: But it concerns you I should speak with you, good Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: That's a good one i'faith, thou know'st breeding well, that I should whisper with a Serving-man before company.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Remember, Sir, last time it had been better—

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Peace, or I'le make you feel my double Fists; If I don't fright him, the sawcy Rogue will call me fool before the Company.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: That was acted most naturally again.

sp.speaker: Sir John. to him.
sp.l: But what needs this dissembling, since you are
Resolv'd to quit my Mistress to me?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: I quit my Mistress! that's a good one i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Tell him you have forsaken me.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: I understand you, Madam, you would save
A quarrel; but i'faith I'm not so base:
I'le see him hang'd first.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Madam, my Master is convinc'd, in prudence
He should say so: but Love o'remasters him;
When you are gone perhaps he may.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: I'le go then: Gentlemen, your Servant;
I see my presence brings constraint to the Company.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: I'm glad she's gone; now we may talk more freely;
For if you have not quitted her, you must.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, remember your self; did not you send me of a message to Sir John, that for his friendship you had left Mistress Millisent.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: Why, what an impudent lying Rogue art thou!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: How's this! has Warner cheated me?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Do not suspect it in the least: you know, Sir,
It was not generous before a Lady,
To say he quitted her.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: O! was that it?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: That was all: say, Yes good Sir John— or I'le swinge you.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: Yes, good Sir John.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: That's well, once in his life he has heard good counsel.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Heigh, Heigh, what makes my Landlord here? he has put on a Fools Coat I think to make us laugh.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: The Devil's in him; he's at it again; his folly's like a sore in a surfeited Horse; cure it in one place, and it breaks out in another.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: Honest Landlord i'faith, and what make you here?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Are you acquainted with this honest man?

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.l: Take heed what you say, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Take heed what I say, Sir, why? who should I be afraid of? of you, Sir? I say, Sir, I know him, Sir; and I have reason to know him, Sir, for I am sure I lodge in his House, Sir,— nay never think to terrifie me, Sir; 'tis my Landlord here in Charles Street, Sir.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Now I expect to be paid for the News I brought him.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Sirrah, did not you tell me that my Father—

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Is in very good health, for ought I know, Sir; I beseech you to trouble your self no farther concerning him.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Who set you on to tell this lye?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I, who set you on Sirrah? this was a Rogue that would cozen us both; he thought I did not know him: down on your marribones and confess the truth: have you no tongue you Rascal?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Sure 'tis some silenc'd Minister: he's grown so sat he cannot speak.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Why, Sir, if you would know, 'twas for your sake I did it.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: For my Masters sake! why you impudent Varlet, do you think to 'scape us with alye?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: How was it for his sake?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: 'Twas for his own, Sir; he heard you were th'occasion the Lady lodg'd not at his House, and so he invented this lye; partly to revenge himself of you; and partly, I believe, in hope to get her once again when you were gone.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Fetch me a Cudgel prithee.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: O good Sir! if you beat me I shall run into oyl immediately,

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Hang him Rogue; he's below your anger: I'le maul him for you— the Rogue's so big, I think 'twill ask two days to beat him all over.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: O Rogue, O Villain Warner! bid him hold
And I'le confess, Sir.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Get you gone without replying: must such as you be prating?
sp.stage: Enter Rose. Sir, Dinner waits you on the Table.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Friend will you go along, and take part of a bad Repast?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: Thank you; but I am just risen from Table.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Now he might fit with his Mistress, and has not the wit to find it out.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: You shall be very welcome.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: I have no stomach, Sir.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Get you in with a vengeance: you have a better stomack than you think you have.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: This hungry Diego Rogue would shame me;
He thinks a Gentleman can eat like a Servingman.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: If you will not, adieu dear Sir;
In any thing command me.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Now we are alone; han't I carry'd matters bravely, Srrah.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: O yes, yes, you deserve Sugar Plums; first for Your quarrelling with Sir John; then for discovering your Landlord, and lastly for refusing to dine with your Mistress: All this is since the last reckoning was wip'd out.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Then why did my Landlord disguise himself, to make a Fool of us?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: You have so little Brains, that a Penn'orth of Butter melted under 'um, would set 'um afloat: he put on that disguise to rid you of your Rival.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: Why, Was not I worthy to keep your counsel then?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: It had been much at one: you would but have drunk the secret down; and piss'd it out to the next company.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Well, I find I am a miserable man: I have lost my Mistress, and may thank my self for't.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: You'l not confess you are a fool, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: Well I am a fool, if that will satisfie you: but
What am I the nearer for being one?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: O yes, much the nearer; for now Fortune's bound to provide for you; As Hospita's are built for lame people, because they cannot help themselves.
Well; I have yet a project in my pate.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: Dear Rogue, What is't?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Excuse me for that: but while 'tis set a working
You would do well to scrue your self into her
Fathers good opinion.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: If you will not tell me, my mind gives me I shall discover it again.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: I'l lay it as far out of your reach as I can possible.
— For secrets are edg'd Tools;
And must be kept from Children and from Fools.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: YOur Worship's most happily encounter'd.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.l: Your Ladiship's most fortunately met.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: I was going to your Lodging.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.l: My business was to yours.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: I have something to say to you that—

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.l: I have that to tell you—

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: Understand then—

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.l: If you'l hear me—

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: I believe that—

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.l: I am of opinion that—

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: Prithee hold thy peace a little till I have done.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: Cry you mercy, Mistress Rose, I'l not dispute your ancient priviledges of talking.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: My Mistress, knowing Sir John was to be abroad upon business this Afternoon, has asked leave to see a Play: and Sir John has so great a confidence of your Master, that he will trust nobody with her, but him.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: If my Master gets her out, I warrant her, he shall show her a better Play than any is at either of the Houses— here they are: I'le run and prepare him to wait upon her.
sp.stage: Enter Old Moody, Mistress Millesent, and Lady Dupe.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: My Hoods and Scarfs there, quickly.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Send to call a Coach there.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: But what kind of man is this Sir Martin, with whom you are to go?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: A plain down-right Country Gentleman, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.l: I like him much the better for't.
For I hate one of those you call a man o'th' Town,
One of those empty fellows of meer out-side:
They've nothing of the true old English manliness.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: I confess, Sir, a Woman's in a sad condition, that has nothing to trust to, but a Perriwig above, and a well-trim'd shoe below.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: This, Sir, is Sir John's friend, he is for your humour, Sir, He is no man o'th' Town, but bred up in the old Elizabeth way of plainness.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I, Madam, your Ladiship may say your pleasure of me.

sp.speaker: Warn:
sp.p: How the Devil got he here before me! 'Tis very unlucky I could not see him first—

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: But, as for Painting, Musick, Poetry, and the like, I'l say this of my self—

sp.speaker: Warn:
sp.p: I'l say that for him, my Master understands none of 'um, I assure you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: You impudent Rascal, hold your Tongue: I must rid my hands of this fellow; the Rogue is ever discrediting me before Company.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Never trouble yourself about it, Sir, for I like a man that—

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I know you do, Sir, and therefore I hope you'll think never the worse of me for his prating: for, though I do not boast of my own good parts—

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: He has none to boast of, upon my faith, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Give him not the hearing, Sir; for, if I may believe my friends, they have flatter'd me with an opinion of more—

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Of more than their flattery can make good, Sir;— 'tis true he tells you, they have flatter'd him; but, in my Conscience he is the most downright simple natur'd creature in the world.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I shall consider you here after Sirrah; but I am sure in all Companies I pass for a Vertuoso.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: Vertuoso! What's that too? is not Vertue enough without O so?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: You have Reason, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: There he is again too; the Town Phrase, a great Compliment I wiss; you have Reason, Sir; that is, you are no beast, Sir.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: A word in private: Sir; you mistake this old man; he loves neither Painting, Musick, nor Poetry; yet recover your self, if you have any brains.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Say you so? I'le bring all about again I warrant you— I beg your pardon a thousand times Sir; I vow to Gad I am not Master of any of those perfections; for in fine. Sir, I am wholly ignorant of Painting, Musick, and Poetry; Only some rude escapes—— but, in fine, they are such, that, In fine, Sir—

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: This is worse than all the rest.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: By Coxbones one word more of all this Gibberish, and old Madge shall fly about your ears: What is this in fine he keeps such a coil with too?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: 'Tis a Phrase a-la-mode, Sir, and is us'd in conversation now, as a whiff of Tobacco was formerly, in the midst of a discourse, for a thinking while.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: In plain English, in fine, is in the end, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: But by Coxbones there is no end on't me thinks: If thou wilt have a foolish word to lard thy lean discourse with, take an English one when thou speakest English; as So Sir, and Then Sir, and so forth; 'tis a more manly kind of nonsence: and a Pox of In fine, for I'l hear no more on't.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: He's gravell'd, and I must help him out.
Madam, there's a Coach at Door to carry you to the Play.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: Which House do you mean to go to?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: The Dukes, I think.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: It is a damn'd Play, and has nothing in't.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Then let us to the Kings.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: That's e'ne as bad.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: This is past enduring.
sp.p: There was an ill Play set up, Sir, on the Posts, but I can assure you the Bills are altered since you saw 'um, and now there are two admirable Comedies at both Houses.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.l: But my Daughter loves serious Plays.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: They are Tragi-Comedies, Sir, for both.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: I have heard her say she loves none but Tragedies.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.l: Where have you heard her say so, Sir?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Sir you forget your self, you never saw her in your life before.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: What not at Canterbury, in the Cathedral Church there? this is the impudentest Rascal—

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Mum, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Ah Lord, what have I done! as I hope to be sav'd, Sir, it was before I was aware; for if ever I set eyes on her before this day— I wish—

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: This fellow is not so much fool, as he makes one believe he is.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: I thought he would be discovered for a wit: this 'tis to over act ones part!

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: Come away Daughter I will not trust you in his hands; there's more in't than I imagin'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Why do you frown upon me so, when you know your looks go to the heart of me; what have I done besides a little lapsus linguae?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Why, who sayes you have done any thing? you, a meer Innocent.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: As the Child's that be born in my intentions, If I know how I have offended my self any more than in one word.—

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: But don't follow me however— I have nothing to say to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: I'le follow you to the worlds end, till you forgive me.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: I am resolv'd to lead you a Dance then.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: The Rogue has no mercy in him, but I must mollifie him with money.

Truly my little Cousin's the aptest Scholar, and takes our loves lessons so exactly that I joy to see it: she has got already the Bond of two thousand pounds seal'd for her Portion, which I keep for her; a pretty good beginning: 'tis true, I believe he has enjoy'd her, and so let him; Mark Anthony wooed not at so dear a price.
O Madam, I fear I am breeding!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: A taking Wench! but 'tis no matter; have you told any body?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I have been venturing upon your foundations, a little to dissemble.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: That's a good Child, I hope it will thrive with thee, as it has with me: Heaven has a blessing in store upon our endeavours.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I feign'd my self sick, and kept my bed; my Lord, he came to visit me, and in the end I disclos'd it to him in the saddest passion.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: This frighted him, I hope, into a study how to cloak your disgrace, lest it should have vent to his Lady.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: 'Tis true; but all the while I subt'ly drove it, that he should name you to me as the fittest instrument of the concealment; but how to break it to you, strangely does perplex him: he has been seeking you all o'r the house; therefore I'l leave your Ladiship, for fear we should be seen together.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Now I must play my part.
Nature, in Women, teaches more than Art.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Madam, I have a Secret to impart.
A sad one too, and have no friend to trust but only you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Your Lady or your Children sick?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Not that I know.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You seem to be in health,

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: In body, not in mind.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Some scruple of Conscience, I warrrant; my Chaplain shall resolve you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Madam, my Soul's tormented.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O take heed of despair, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Madam, there is no Medicine for this siekness, but only you; your friendship's my safe Haven, else I am lost and shipwrack'd.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Pray tell me what it is.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Could I express it by sad sighs and groans,
Or drown it with my self in Seas of Tears,
I should be happy, would, and would not tell.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Command whatever I can serve you in,
I will be faithful still to all your ends, provided they be just and vertuous.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: That word has stopt me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Speak out, my Lord, and boldly tell what 'tis.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Then in obedience to your Commands; your Cousin is with Child.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Which Cousin?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Your Cousin Christian's here ith' house.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Alass then she has stoln a Marriage, and undone her self: Some young Fellow, on my Conscience, that's a Beggar; Youth will not be advis'd; well, I'l never meddle more with Girls; One is no more assur'd of 'um than Grooms of Mules, they'l strike when least one thinks on't: but pray your Lordship, what is her choice then for an Husband?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: She is not married that I know of, Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Not married! 'tis impossible, the Girl does sure abuse you. I know her Education has been such, the flesh could not prevail; therefore she does abuse you, it must be so.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Madam, not to abuse you longer, she is with Child, and I the unfortunate man who did this most unlucky act.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You! I'l never believe it.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Madam, 'tis too true; believe it, and be serious how to hide her shame; I beg it here upon my knees.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Oh, oh, oh.—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Who's there? Whose there? help, help, help.

sp.speaker: 1 VVom.
sp.l: O merciful God, my Lady's gone!

sp.speaker: 2 VVom.
sp.l: Whither?

sp.speaker: 1 VVom.
sp.l: To Heaven, God knows, to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: Rub her, rub her; fetch warm Cloaths.

sp.speaker: 2 VVom.
sp.p: I say, run to the Cabinet of Quintessence; Gilberts Water, Gilberts Water.

sp.speaker: 1 Wom.
sp.l: Now all the good Folks of heaven look down upon her.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Set her in the Chair.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: Open her mouth with a Dagger or a Key; pour, pour,
Where's the Spoon?

sp.speaker: 2 Wom.
sp.p: She stirs, she revives, merciful to us all, what a thing was this! speak, Lady, speak.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: So, so, so.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Alas, my Lord, How came this fit?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: With Sorrow, Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Now I am better: Bess, you have not seen me thus.

sp.speaker: 1 Wom.
sp.l: Heav'n forefend that I should live to see you so agen.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Go, go, I'm pretty well; withdraw into the next Room but be near I pray, for fear of the worst.

— My Lord, sit down near me I pray, I'le strive to speak a few words to you, and then to Bed,— nearer, my voice is faint.— My Lord, Heaven knows how I have ever lov'd you; and, Is this my reward? Had you none to abuse but me in that unfortunate fond Girl that you know was dearer to me than my life? this was not love to her, but an inveterate malice to poor me. Oh, oh.—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Help, help, help.

sp.speaker: 1 Wom.
sp.l: This fit will carry her: alass it is a Lechery!

sp.speaker: 2 Wom.
sp.l: The Balsom, the Balsom!

sp.speaker: 1 VVoman.
sp.p: No no, the Chymistry Oyl of Rosemary: hold her up, and give her Air.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Feel whether she breathes, with your hand before her Mouth.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: No, Madam, 'tis Key-cold.

sp.speaker: 1 VVom.
sp.p: Look up, dear Madam, if you have any hope of Salvation!

sp.speaker: 2 VVom.
sp.p: Hold up your finger, Madam, if you have any hope of Fraternity. O the blessed Saints that hear me not, take her Mortality to them.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Enough, so, 'tis well,— withdraw, and let me rest a while; only my dear Lord remain.

sp.speaker: 1 VVom.
sp.l: Pray your Lordship keep her from swebbing.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Here humbly once again, I beg your pardon and your help.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Heaven forgive you, and I do: stand up, my Lord, and sit close by me: O this naughty Girl! but did your Lordship win her soon?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: No, Madam, but with much difficulty.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I'm glad on't; it shew'd the Girl had some Religion in her, all my Precepts were not in vain: but you men are strange tempters; good my Lord, where was this wicked act then first committed?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: In an out-room upon a Trunk.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Poor Heart, what shift Love makes! Oh she does love you dearly, though to her ruine! and then what place, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: An old waste Room, with a decay'd Bed in't.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Out upon that dark Room for deeds of darkness! and that rotten Bed! I wonder it did hold your Lordships vigour: but you dealt gently with the Girl. Well, you shall see I love you: for I will manage this business to both your advantages, by the assistance of Heaven I will; good my Lord help, lead me out.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: A mischief upon all Fools! do you think your Master has not done wisely? first to mistake our old mans humour, then to dispraise the Plays; and lastly, to discover his Acquaintance with my Mistress: my old Master has taken such a Jealousie of him, that he will never admit him into his sight again.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Thou mak'st thy self a greater Fool than he by being angry at what he cannot help— I have been angry with him too; but these friends have taken up the quarrel.—

Look you he has sent these Mediators to mitigate your wrath: here are twenty of 'um have made a long Voyage from Guinny to kiss your hands: and when the Match is made, there are an hundred more in readiness to be your humble Servants.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Rather then fall out with you, I'l take u'm; but I confess it troubles me to see so loyal a Lover have the heart of an Emperour, and yet scarce the brains of a Cobler.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Well, what device can we two beget betwixt us, to separate Sir John Swallow and thy Mistress?

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: I cannot on the sudden tell; but I hate him worse than foul weather without a Coach.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: Then I'l see if my project will be luckier than thine. Where are the Papers concerning the Joynture I have heard you speak of?

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: They lie within in three great Bags, some twenty Reams of Paper in each Bundle, with six lines in a sheet: but there is a little Paper where all the business lies.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.l: Where is it? Canst thou help me to it?

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: By good chance he gave it to my custody before he set out for London. You came in good time, here it is, I was carrying it to him; just now he sent for it.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: So, this I will secure in my Pocket: when thou art ask'd for it, make two or three bad faces, and say, 'twas left behind: by this means he must of necessity leave the Town, to see for it in Kent.
sp.stage: Enter Sir John, Sir Martin, Mrs. Mill.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, though the old man be suspicious; I knew the story all before-hand; and since then you have fully satisfi'd me of your true friendship to me— Where are the Writings?

sp.speaker: Rose. Sir,
sp.p: I beg your pardon; I thought I had put 'um up amongst my Ladies things, and it seems in my haste I quite forgot 'um, and left 'um at Canterbury.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: This is horribly unlucky! Where do you think you left 'um?

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Upon the great Box in my Ladies Chamber; they are safe enough I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: It must be so— I must take Post immediately:
Madam, for some few dayes I must be absent;
And to confirm you, friend, how much I trust you,
I leave the dearest Pledge I have on Earth,
My Mistress, to your care.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: If you lov'd me, you would not take all occasions to leave me thus!

sp.speaker: Warn aside.
sp.p: Do, go to Kent, and when you come again, Here they are ready for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: What's that you have in your hand there.
Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Pox, What ill luck was this! What shall I say?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Sometimes you've tongue enough, what, are you silent?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: 'Tis an Accompt, Sir, of what Money you have lost since you came to Town.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I'm very glad on't: now I'l make you all see the severity of my Fortune,— give me the Paper.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Heaven! What does he mean to do? it is not fair writ out, Sir;

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Besides, I am in haste, another time, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Pray, oblige me, Sir,—— 'tis but one minute: all people love to be pitty'd in their Misfortunes, and so do I: will you produce it, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Dear Master!

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: Dear Rascal! am I Master or you? you Rogue!

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Hold yet, Sir, and let me read it:— you cannot read my hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: This is ever his way to be disparaging me,— but I'le let you see, Sirrah, that I can read your hand better than you your self can.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: You'l repent it, there's a trick in't, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Is there so, Sirrah? but I'le bring you out of all your Tricks with a Vengeance to you.—
How now! What's this? A true particular of the Estate of Sir John Swallow Knight, lying and scituate in, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: This is the very Paper I had lost: I'm very [Takes the glad on't, it has sav'd me a most unwelcome journey,— (Paper. but I will not thank you for the Courtesie, which now I find you never did intend me— this is Confederacy, I smoak it now— Come, Madam, let me wait on you to your Father.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Well, of a witty man, this was the foolishest part that ever I beheld.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I am a Fool, I must confess it, and I am the most miserable one without thy help,— but yet it was such a mistake as any man might have made.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: No doubt on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Prethee chide me! this indifference of thine wounds me to the heart.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: I care not.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: Wilt thou not help me for this once?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Sir, I kiss your hands, I have other business.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: Dear Warner!

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: I am inflexible.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: Then I am resolv'd I'l kill my self.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: You are Master of your own Body.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: Will you let me damn my Soul?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: At your pleasure, as the Devil and you can agree about it.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: D'ye see the points ready? Will you do nothing to save my life?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Not in the least.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: Farewell, hard-harted Warner.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Adieu soft-headed Sir Martin.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Why don't you dispatch, Sir? Why all these Preambles?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I'l see thee hang'd first: I know thou won'dst have me kill'd, to get my Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: I knew it was but a Copy of your Countenance; people in this Age are not so apt to kill themselves.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Here are yet ten Pieces in my Pocket, take 'em, and let's be friends.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: You know the Eas'ness of my Nature, and that makes you work upon it so. Well, Sir,— for this once I cast an Eye of pity on you,— but I must have ten more in hand, before I can stir a foot.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: As I am a true Gamester, I have lost all but these,— but if thou'lt lend me them, I'l give 'em thee agen.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.l: I'l rather trust you till to morrow;
Once more look up, I bid you hope the best.
Why should your folly make your Love miscarry,
Since men first play the Fools, and then they marry?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: BUT are they to be married this day in private, say you?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: 'Tis so concluded, Sir, I dare assure you.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: But why so soon, and in private?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: So soon to prevent the designs upon her; and in private, to save the effusion of Christian Money.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: It strikes to my heart already; in fine, I am a dead man.— Warner.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Well, go your ways, I'le try what may be done. Look if he will stir now; your Rival and the Old man will see us together, we are just below the Window.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: Thou can'st not do't.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: On the peril of my twenty pieces be it.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: But I have found a way to help thee out, trust to my wit but once.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Name your wit, or think you have the least grain of wit once more, and I'le lay it down for ever.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: You are a sawcy masterly Companion, and so I leave you.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Help, help, good People, Murther, Murther!

sp.speaker: Sir John and Moody,
sp.l: How now, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: I am abus'd, I am beaten, I am lam'd for ever.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.l: Who has us'd thee so?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: The Rogue my Master.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: What was the Offence?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: A trifle, just nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: That's very strange.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p:
It was for telling him he lost too much at Play; I
meant him nothing but well, Heaven knows, and he in a cursed damn'd humour would needs revenge his losses upon me: A' kick'd me, took away my money, and turn'd me off; but if I take it at his hands—

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: By Cox nowns it was an ill-natur'd part, nay, I thought no better could come on't, when I heard him at his Vow to Gads, and in fines.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: But if I live I'll cry quittance with him: he had engag'd me to get Mrs. Millisent your Daughter for him; but if I do not all that ever I can to make her hate him, a great Booby, an overgrown Oafe, a conceited Bartlemew.—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Prithee leave off thy Choler, and hear me a little: I have had a great mind to thee a long time, if thou think'st my Service better than his, from this minute I entertain thee.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir, and so much the rather, that I may spight him with it.— This was the most propitious Fate.—

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: Propitious! and Fate! what a damn'd Scander-bag-Rogue art thou to talk at this rate! hark you, Sirrah, one word more of this Gibberish, and I'll set you packing from your new Service; I'll have neither Propitious nor Fate come within my doors.——

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Nay, pray Father.—

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Good old Sir be pacified I was pouring out a little of the dregs that I had left in me of my former Service, and now they are gone, my stomachs clear of 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: This Fellow is come in a happy hour; for now, Sir, you and I may go to prepare the Licence, and in the mean time he may have an Eye upon your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: If you please I'll wait upon her till she's ready, and then bring her to what Church you shall appoint.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: But, Friend, you'l find she'l hang an Arse, and be very loth to come along with you, and therefore I had best stay behind, and bring her my self.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: I warrant you I have a trick for that, Sir, she knows nothing of my being turn'd away: So I'll come to her as from Sir Martin, and under pretence of carrying her to him, conduct her to you,

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: My better Angel—

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: By th' mess 'twas well thought on; well Son, go you before, I'l speak but one word for a Dish or two at Dinner, and follow you to the Licence-Office. Sirrah— stay you here— till my return.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: solus. Was there ever such a lucky Rogue as I! I had alwayes a good opinion of my wit, but could never think I had so much as now I find. I have now gain'd an opportunity to carry away Mistress Millisent for my Master, to get his Mistress by means of his Rival, to receive all his happiness, where he could expect nothing but misery: after this exploit I will have Lilly draw me in the Habit of a Hero, with a Lawrel on my Temples, and an Inscription below it, This is Warner the flower of Serving-men.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Pray do me the favour to help me to the speech of Mr. Moody.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.l: What's your business?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: I have a Letter to deliver to him.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Here he comes, you may deliver it your self to him.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Sir, a Gentleman met me at the Corner of the next Street, and bid me give this into your own hands.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.l: Stay friend, till I have read it.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: He told me, Sir, it required no Answer.

sp.speaker: Mood. reads.

p.hi: Sir, permit me, though a stranger, to give you counsel; some young Gallants have had intelligence, that this day you intend privately to Marry your Daughter, the rich Heiress; and in fine, above twenty of them have dispersed themselves to watch her going out: therefore put it off, if you will avoid mischief, and be advised by

sp.p: Your unknown Servant.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p:
By the Mackings, I thought there was no good in't, when I saw in fine there; there are some Papishes, I'l warrant, that lie in wait for my Daughter, or else they are no Englishmen, but some of your French Outalion-Rogues; I owe him Thanks
however, this unknown Friend of mine, that told me on't. Warner, no Wedding to day, Warner.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Why, What's the matter. Sir?

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: I say no more, but some wiser than some, I'l keep my Daughter at home this Afternoon, and a fig for all these Outalians.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: So, here's another Trick of Fortune as unexpected for bad, as the other was for good. Nothing vexes me, but that I had made my Game Cock-sure, and then to be back-gammon'd: it must needs be the Devil that writ this Letter, he ow'd my Master a spight, and has paid him to the purpose: and here he comes as merry too, he little thinks what misfortune has befal'n him, and for my part I am asham'd to tell him.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.l: Warner, such a Jest, Warner.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: What a Murrain is the matter, Sir?
Where lies this Jest that tickles you?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Let me laugh out my langh, and I'l tell thee.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: I wish you may have cause for all this mirth.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Hereafter, Warner, be it known unto thee, I will endure no more to be thy May game: thou shal't no more dare to tell me, I spoil thy projects, and discover thy designs; for I have play'd such a Prize, without thy help, of my own Mother-wit ('tis true I am hasty sometimes, and so do harm; but when I have a mind to shew my self, there's no man in England, though I say't, comes near me as to point of imagination) I'l make thee acknowledge I have laid a Plot that has a Soul in't.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, keep me no longer in ignorance of this rare Invention.

sp.speaker: Sir. Mart.
sp.p: Know then, Warner, that when I left thee, I was possest with a terrible fear, that my Mistress should be married: well, thought I to my self, and must'ring up all the Forces of my Wit, I did produce such a stratagem.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: But what was it?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p:
I feign'd a Letter as from an unknown Friend to Moody, wherein I gave him to understand, that if his Daughter went out this Afternoon, she would infallibly be snapt by some
young Fellows that lay in wait for her.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: That which follows is yet better; for he I fent assures me, that in that very nick of time my Letter came, her Father was just sending her abroad with a very foolish rascally fellow that was with him.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: And did you perform all this a'gods name? could you do this wonderful miracle without your soul to the Devil for his help?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I tell thee man I did it, and it was done by the help of no Devil, but this familiar of my own brain; how long would it have been e're thou couldest have thought of such a project? Martin said to his man, Who's the Fool now?

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: Who's the fool? why who use to be the fool? he that ever was since I knew him, and ever will be so!

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: What a Pox? I think thou art grown envious, not one word in my commendations?

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: Faith Sir, my skill is too little to praise you as you deserve; but if you would have it according to my poor ability, you are one that had a knock in your Cradle, a conceited lack-wit, a designing Ass, a hair-brain'd Fop, a confounded busie brain, with an eternal Wind mill in it; this in short, Sir, is the Contents of your Panegyrick.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: But what the Devil have I done, to set you thus against me?

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: Only this, Sir, I was the foolish rascally fellow that was with Moody, and your Worship was he to whom I was to bring his Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: But how could I know this? I am no Witch.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.l: No, I'll be sworn for you, you are no Conjurer.
Will you go Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Will you hear my justifications?

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: Shall I see the back of you? speak not a word in your defence.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: This is the strangest luck now—

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: I'am resolv'd this Devil of his shall never weary me, I will overcome him, I will invent something that shall stand good in spight of his folly. Let me see—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Here he is— I must venture on him, for the tyranny of this old Lady is unsupportable, since I have made her my confident, there passes not an hour but she passes a pull at my Purse-strings; I sha'l be ruin'd if I do not quit my self of her suddenly: I find now, by sad experience, that a Mistress is much more chargeable than a Wife, and after a little time too, grows full as dull and insignificant. Mr. VVarner! have you a mind to do your self a courtesie, and me another?

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: I think, my Lord, the Question need not be much dissputed, for I have alwayes had a great service for your Lordship, and some little kindness for my self.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: What, if you should propose Mistress Christian as a Wife to your Master? you know he's never like to compass t'other.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: I cannot tell that my Lord—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: 500 l. are yours at the day of marriage.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: 500 l. 'tis true, the temptation is very sweet, and powerful; the Devil I confess has done his parr, and many a good Murder and Treason have been committed at a cheaper rate; but yet—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: What yet—

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: To confess the truth, I am resolv'd to bestow my Master upon that other Lady (as difficult as your Lordship thinks it) for the honour of my wit is engag'd in it: will it not be the same to your Lordship were she marred to any other?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: The very same.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Come my Lord, not to dissemble with you any longer, I know where it is that your Shoe wrings you: I have observ'd something in the House, betwixt some parties that shall be nameless: and know that you have been taking up Linnen at a much dearer rate, than you might have had it at any Drapers in Town.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I see I have not danc'd in a Net before you.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: As for that old Lady, whom Hell confound, she is the greatest Jill in Nature, cheat is her study, all her joy to cosen, she loves nothing but her self, and draws all lines to that corrupted centre.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
I have found her out, though late: first, I'll undertake
I n'er enjoy'd her Neice under the rate of 500 l. a time; never was Womans flesh held up so high: every night I find out for a new Maiden-head, and she has sold it me as often as ever Mother Temple, Bennet, or Gifford, have put off boil'd Capons for Quails and Partridges.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: This is nothing to what Bills you'l have when she's brought to Bed, after her hard bargain, as they call it; then cram'd Capons, Pea-hens, Chickens in the grease, Pottages, and Frigacies, Wine from Shatling, and La-fronds, with New-River, clearer by six pence the pound than ever God Almighty made it; then Midwife— Dry-Nurse— Wet-Nurse— and all the rest of their Accomplices, with Cradle, Baby-Clouts, and Bearing-Cloaths— Possets, Cawdels, Broth, Jellies, and Gravies; and behind all these, Glisters, Suppositers, and a barbarous Pothecaries Bill, more inhumane than a Tailors.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I sweat to think on't.

sp.speaker: Warn.
