sp.p: Well, my Lord! chear up! I have found a way to rid you of it all, within a short time you shall know more; yonder appears a young Lady whom I must needs speak with, please you go in and prepare the old Lady and your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Good luck, and 500 l. attend thee.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: I am resolv'd I'l never marry him!

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: So far you are right, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: But, how to hinder it, I cannot possibly tell? for my Father presses me to it, and will take no denial: wou'd I knew some way—

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Madam, I'l teach you the very nearest, for I have just now found it out,

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Are you there, Mr. Littleplot?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Studying to deserve thee, Rose, by my diligence for thy Lady; I stand here, methinks, just like a wooden Mercury, to point her out the way to Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Or, Serving-man-like, ready to carry up the hot meat for your Master, and then to fall upon the cold your self.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p:
I know not what you call the cold, but I believe I shall
find warm work on't: in the first place then I must acquaint you, that I have seemingly put off my Master, and entred my self into Sir John's service.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Most excellent!

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: And thereupon, but base—

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Something he would tell us, but see what luck's here!

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: How now, Sirrah? are you so great there already?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: I find my Father's jealous of him still!

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Sir, I was only teaching my young Lady a new Song, and if you please you shall hear it.

lg.l: Make ready fair Lady to night,
And stand at the Door below,
For I will be there
To receive you with care,
And to your true Love you shall go.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: Ods bobs this is very pretty.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: I, so is the Lady's Answer too, if I could but hit on't.

lg.l: And when the Stars twinckle so bright,
Then down to the Door will I creep,
To my Love will I flye,
E're the jealous can spye,
And leave my old daddy asleep.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: Bodikins I like not that so well, to cosen her old Father; it may be my own case another time.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Oh Madam! yonder's your Persecutor return'd.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: I'll into my Chamber to avoid the sight of him as long as I can; Lord! that my old doting Father should throw me away upon such an Ignoramus, and deny me to such a Wit as Sir Martin.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: O Son! here has been the most villainous Tragedy against you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What Tragedy? has there been any blood shed since I went?

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: No blood shed, but, as I told you, a most damnable Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: A Tragedy! I'll be hang'd if he does not mean a Stratagem.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: Jack Sawce! if I say it is a Tragedy, it shall be a Tragedy in spight of you, teach your Grandam how to piss— what— I hope I am old enough how to spout English with you Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But what was the reason you came not after me?

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: 'T was well I did not, I'll promise you, there were those would have made bold with Mistress Bride; an' if she had stir'd out of doors, there were Whipsters abroad i'faith, Padders of Maiden-heads, that would have truss'd her up, and pick'd the lock of her affections, e'r a man could have said, what's this: but by good luck I had warning of it by a friends Letter.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: The remedy for all such dangers is easie, you may send for a Parson, and have the business dispatch'd at home.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: A match, i'faith, do you provide a Domine, and I'll go tell her our resolutions, and hearten her up against the day of battel.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Now I think on't, this Letter must needs come from Sir Martin; a Plot of his, upon my life, to hinder our marriage.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: I see, Sir, you'l still mistake him for a Wit; but I am much deceiv'd, if that Letter came not from another hand.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: From whom I prithee?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Nay, for that you shall excuse me, Sir, I do not love to make a breach betwixt persons that are to be so near related.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Thou seem'st to imply that my Mistress was in the Plot,

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Can you make a doubt on't? do you not know she ever lov'd him, and can you hope she has so soon forsaken him? you may make your self miserable, if you please, by such a marriage.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: When she is once mine, her Vertue will secure me.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Her Vertue!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What, do you make a mock on't?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Not I, I assure you, Sir, I think it no such jesting matter.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Why, is she not honest?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Yes in my conscience is she, for Sir Martin's Tongue's no slander.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But does she say to the contrary?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: If one would believe him, which for my part I do not, he has in a manner confess'd it to me.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Hell and Damnation!

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Courage, Sir, never vex your self, I'll warrant you 'tis all a Lye.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But how shall I be ' sut'd 'tis so?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: When you are married you'l soon make tryal, whether she be a Maid or no?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I do not love to make that Experiment at my own cost.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: Then you must never marry.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I, but they have so many tricks to cheat a man, which are entay'ld from Mother to Daughter through all Generations, there's no keeping a Lock for that Door for which every one has a Key.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: As for Example, their drawing up their breaths with Oh! you hurt me, can you be so cruel? then the next day she steals a Visit to her Lover, that did you the Courtesie before-hand, and in private tells him how she cozened you; twenty to one but she takes out another Lesson with him to practise the next night.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: All this while miserable I must be their May-game.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: 'Tis well if you escape so; for commonly he strikes in with you, and becomes your friend.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Deliver me from such a friend that stays behind with my Wife, When I gird on my Sword to go abroad.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: I, there's your man, Sir; besides he will be sure to watch your haunts, and tell her of them, that if occasion be, she may have wherewithall to recriminate: at least she will seem to be jealous of you, and who would suspect a jealous Wife?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: All manner of ways I am most miserable.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: But if she be not a Maid when you marry her, she may make a good Wife afterwards, 'tis but imagining you have taken such a mans Widow.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: If there were all; but the Man will come and claim her again.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Examples have been frequent of those that have been wanton, and yet afterwards take up.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I, the same thing they took up before.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: The truth is, an honest simple Girl that's ignorant of all things, maketh the best Matrimony: There is such pleasure in instructing her, the best is, there's not one Dunce in all the Sex; such a one with a good Fortune—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I, but where is she, Warner?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Near enough, but that you are too far engag'd.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Engag'd to one that hath given me the earnest of Cuckoldom before-hand?

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: What think you then of Mrs Christian here in the house? There's 5000 l. and a better penny.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I, but is she Fool enough?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: She's none of the wise Virgins, I can assure you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Dear Warner, step into the next Room, and inveigle her out this way, that I may speak to her.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Remember above all things, you keep this Wooing secret; if he takes the least wind, old Moody will be sure to hinder it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Do'st thou think I shall get her Aunts Consent?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Leave that to me.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: How happy a man shall I be, if I can but compass this! and what a Precipice have I avoided! then the revenge too is so sweet to steal a Wife under her Fathers nose, and leave 'um in the lurch who has abus'd me; well, such a Servant as this, Warner, is a Jewel.
sp.stage: Enter Warner and Mrs. Christian to him.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: There she is, Sir, now I'll go to prepare her Aunt.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Sweet Mistress, I am come to wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Truly you are too good to wait on me.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And in the Condition of a Suitor.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: As how, forsooth?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: To be so happy as to marry you.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: O Lord, I would not marry for any thing!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Why? 'tis the honest end of Woman-kind.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Twenty years hence, forsooth: I would not lye in bed with a man for a world, their beards it will so prickle one.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Pah,— What an innocent Girl it is, and very child! I like a Colt that never yet was back'd; for so I shall make her what I list, and mould her as I will; Lord! her innocency makes me laugh my Cheeks all wet.— Sweet Lady—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I'm but a Gentlew man, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Well then, sweet Mistress, if I get your Friends consent sha'l I have yours?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: My old Lady may do what she will, forsooth, but by my truly, I hope she will have more care of me, then to marry me yet; Lord bless me, what should I do with a Husband?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Well, Sweet-heart, then instead of wooing you, I must wooe my old Lady.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Indeed, Gentleman, my old Lady is married already: cry you mercy forsooth, I think you are a Knight.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Happy in that Title only to make you Lady.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Believe me, Mr. Knight, I would not be a Lady, it makes Folks proud, and so humerous, and so ill Huswifes, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Pah,— she's a Baby, the simplest thing that ever yet I knew; the happiest man I shall be in the world; for should I have my wish, it should be to keep School, and teach the bigger Girls, and here in one my wish it is absolv'd.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: By your leave, Sir: I hope this noble Knight will make you happy, and you make him.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What should I make him?

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: Marry, you shall make him happy in a good Wife.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I will not marry, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: You Fool!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, let me speak with you, on my Soul 'tis the pretti'st innocent'st thing in the world.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, she knows little besides her work and her Prayers; but I'll talk with the Fool.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Deal gently with her, dear Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: Come, Christian, will not you marry this noble Knight?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yes, yes, yes.—

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: Sir, it shall be to night.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: This Innocence is a Dowry beyond all price.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Martin and Sir John, musing.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: You are very melancholy methinks, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: You are mistaken, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: You may dissemble as you please, but Mrs. Millisent lyes at the bottom of your Heart.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: My Heart, I assure you, has no room for so poor a Trifle.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Sure you think to wheadle me, would you have me imagine you do not love her?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Love her! why should you think me such a Sot? love a Prostitute, and infamous person!

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Fair and soft, good Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: You see I am no very obstinate Rival, I leave the field free to you: go on, Sir, and pursue your good Fortune, and be as happy as such a common Creature can make thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: This is Hebrew-Greek to me; but I must tell you, Sir, I will not suffer my Divinity to be prophan'd by such a Tongue as yours.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Believe it; what'er I say I can quote my Author for.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Then, Sir, whoever told it you, ly'd in his Throat, d'you see, and deeper than that d'ye see, in his stomach, and his guts d'ye see: tell me she's a common person! he's a Son of a Whore that said it, and make him eat his words, though he spoke 'em in a pr●vy-house.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What if Warner told me so? I hope you'l grant him to be a competent Judge in such a business.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Did that precious Rascal say it?— Now I think on't I'll not believe you: in fine, Sir, I'll hold you an even Wager he denies it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I'll lay you ten to one, he justifies it to your face.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I'll make him give up the Ghost under my fist, if he does not deny it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I'll cut off his Ears upon the Spot, if he does not stand to't.
Enter Warner.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Here he comes in Pudding-time to resolve the question: come hither, you lying Varlet, hold up your hand at the Bar of Justice, and answer me to what I shall demand.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: What a Goodier is the matter, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Thou Spawn of the old Serpent, fruitful in nothing but in lyes!

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: A very fair beginning this.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Didst thou dare to cast thy Venom upon such a Saint as Mrs. Millisent, to traduce her Vertue, and say it was adulterate?

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: Not guilty my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I told you so.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: How, Mr. Rascal! have you forgot what you said but now concerning Sir Martin and Mrs. Millisent? I'll stop the Lye down your Throat, if you dare deny't.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Say you so! are you there agen i'faith?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Pray pacifie your self, Sir, 'twas a Plot of my own devising.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Leave off your winking and your pinking, with a Horse-pox t'ye, I'll understand none of it; tell me in plain English the truth of the business: for an'you were my own Brother, you should pay for it: belye my Mistress! what a Pox d'ye think I have no sense of Honour?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: What the Devil's the matter w'ye? either be at quiet, or I'll resolve to take my heels, and be gone.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Stop Thief there! what did you think to scape the hand of Justice?
The best on't is, Sirrah, your heels are not altogether so nimble as your tongue,

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: He p! Murder! Murder!

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Confess, you Rogue, then.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Hold your hands, I think the Devil's in you,— I tell you 'tis a device of mine.

sp.speaker: Sir. Mart.
sp.p: And have you no body to devise it on but my Mistress, the very Map of Innocence?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Moderate your anger, good Sir Martin.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: By your patience, Sir, I'll chastise him abundantly.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: That's a little too much, Sir, by your favour, to beat him in my presence.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: That's a good one i'faith, your presence shall hinder me from beating my own Servant.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: O Traytor to all sense and reason! he's going to discover that too.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: An'I had a mind to beat him to Mummy, he's my own, I hope.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: At present I must tell you he's mine, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Hey-day! here's fine jugling!

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Stop yet, Sir, you are just upon the brink of a Precipice.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: What is't thou meanest now?—— a Lord! my mind mis-gives me I have done some fault, but would I were hang'd if I can find it out.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: There's no making him understand me.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Pox on't, come what will, I'll not be fac'd down with a Lye; I say he is my man.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Pray remember your self better; did not you turn him away for some fault lately, and laid a Livery of black and blue on his back before he went?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: The Devil of any fault, or any black and blue that I remember: either the Rascal put some Trick upon you, or you would upon me.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: O, ho, then it seems the cudgelling and turning away were pure invention; I am glad I undestand it.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: In fine, it's all so damn'd a Lye.——

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Alas! he has forgot it, Sir, good Wits, you know, have bad Memories.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: No, no, Sir, that shall not serve your turn, you may return when you please to your old Master, I give you a fair discharge, and a glad man I am to be so rid of you: were you thereabouts i'faith? what a Snake I had entertain'd into my bosom? fare you well, Sir, and lay your next Plot better between you, I advise you.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, how you stand! as you were nip'd i'th'head: have you done any new piece of Folly, that makes you look so like an Ass?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Here's three pices of Gold yet, if I had the heart to offer it thee.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Noble Sir, what have I done to deserve so great a Liberality; I confess if you had beaten me for my own fault, if you had utterly destroyed all my projects, then it might ha'bin expected that ten or twenty pieces should have been offer'd by way of recompence or satisfaction.——

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Nay, on'you be so full o'your Flowts, your Friend and Servant; who the Devil could tell the meaning of your signs and tokens, an'you go to that?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: You are no Ass then?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Well, Sir, to do you service, d'ye see, I am an Ass in a fair way; will that satisfie you?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: For this once produce those three pieces, I am contented to receive that inconsiderable tribute, or make'em six and I'll take the fault upon my self.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Are we Friends then? if we are, let me advise you.—

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Yet advising.—

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: For no harm, good Warner: but pray next time make me of your Council, let me enter into the business, instruct me in every point, and then if I discover all, I am resolv'd to give over affairs, and retire from the world.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.l: Agreed, it shall be so; but let us now take breath a while, then on agen.
For though we had the worst, those heats were past,
Wee'l whip and spur, and fetch him up at last.

sp.stage: Enter Lord, Lady Dupe, Mistress Christian, Rose, and Warner.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: YOur promise is admirably made good to me, that Sir John Swallow should be this night married to Mrs. Christian; instead of that, he is more deeply engag'd than ever with old Moody.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: I cannot help these ebbs and flows of fortune.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: I am sure my Niece suffers most in't, he's come off to her with a cold Complement of a mistake in his Mistress's Virtue, which he has now found out, by your Masters folly, to be a Plot of yours to separate them.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: To be forsaken when a woman has given her consent!

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: 'Tis the same scorn, as to have a Town render'd up, and afterwards slighted.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: You are a sweet youth, Sir, to use my Lady so, when she depended on you; is this the faith of Valet de Chambre? I would be asham'd to be such a dishonour to my profession; it will reflect upon us in time, we shall be ruin'd by your good example.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: As how my dear Lady Embassadress?

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Why, they say the Women govern their Ladies, and you govern us: so if you play fast and loose, not a Gallant will bribe us for our good wills; the gentle Guiny will now go to the Ordinary, which us'd as duly to steal into our hands at the stair-foot as into Mr. Doctors at parting.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Night's come, and I expect your promise.

sp.speaker: La. D.
sp.p: Fail with me if you think good, Sir.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I give no more time.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: And if my Mistress go to bed a Maid to night.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p:
Hey dey! you are dealing with me, as they do with the Banquers, call in all your debts together; there's no possibility of payment at this rate, but I'll coin for you all as fast as I
can, I assure you.

sp.speaker: La. Du.
sp.p: But you must not think to pay us with false Money, as you have done hitherto.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Leave off your Mountebank tricks with us, and fall to your business in good earnest.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: Faith, and I will Rose; for to confess the truth, I am a kind of a Mountebank, I have but one Cure for all your Diseases, that is, that my Master may marry Mrs. Millisent, for then Sir John Swallow will of himself return to Mrs. Christian.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: He says true, and therefore we must all be helping to that design.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: I'll put you upon something, give me but a thinking time. In the first place, get a Warrant and Bailifs to arrest Sir John Swallow upon a promise of marriage to Mrs. Christian.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: La. Du.
sp.p: We'll all swear it.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: I never doubted your Ladiship in the least, Madam— for the rest we will consider hereafter.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Leave this to us

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Rose where's thy Lady?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: What have you to say to her?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Only to tell you, Madam, I am going forward in the great work of projection.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: I know not whether you will deserve my thanks when the work's done.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Madam, I hope you are not become indifferent to my Master.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: If he should prove a fool after all your crying up his wit, I shall be a miserable woman.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: A fool! that were a good jest i'faith: but how comes your Ladiship to suspect it?

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: I have heard, Madam, your greatest Wits have ever a touch of madness and extravagance in them, so perhaps has he.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: There's nothing more distant than wit and folly, yet like East and West, they may meet in a point, and produce actions that are but a hairs breadth from one another.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: I'll undertake he has wit enough to make one laugh at him a whole day together: He's a most Comical person,

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: For all this I will not swear he is no fool, he has still discovered all your plots.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: O Madam, that's the common fate of your Machivilians, they draw their Designs so subtile, that their very fineness breaks them.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: However I'm resolv'd to be on the sure side, I will have certain proof of his wit before I marry him.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Madam, I'll give you one, he wears his cloaths like a great Sloven, and that's a sure sign of wit, he neglects his outward parts; besides, he speaks French, sings, dances, plays upon the Lute.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Does he do all this, say you?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Most divinely, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: I ask no more, then let him give me a Serenade immediately; but let him stand in the view, I'll not be cheated,

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: He shall do't Madam: but how, the Devil knows— for he sings like a Scritch-Owle, and never touch'd the Lute.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: You'll see't perform'd?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Now I think on't, Madam, this will but retard our enterprise.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Either let him do't, or see me no more.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Well, it shall be done, Madam; but where's your Father? will not he over hear it?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: As good hap is, he's below stairs, talking with a Seaman, that has brought him news from the East Indies.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: What concernment can he have there?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: He had a Bastard-Son there, whom he loved extremely: but not having any news from him these many year's concluded him dead; this Son he expects within these three dayes.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: When did he see him last?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Not since he was seven years old.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: A sudden thought comes into my head to make him appear before his time; let my Master pass for him, and by that means he may come into the House unsuspected by her Father, or his Rival.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: According as he performs his Serenade, I'll talk with you— make haste— I must retire a little,

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p:
I'll instruct him most rarely, he shall never be found
out; but in the mean time, what wilt thou do with a Serenade?

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: Faith, I am little non-plus'd on the sudden, but a warm consolation from thy lips, Rose, would set my wits a working again.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Adieu, Warner.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Inhumane Rose, adieu. Blockhead Warner, into what a Premunire hast thou brought thy self; this 'tis to be so forward to promise for another— but to be Godfather to a Fool, to promise and vow he should do any thing like a Christian.—

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Why, how now Bully, in a Brown Study? for my good I warrant it; there's five shillings for thee, what, we must encourage good wits sometimes.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Hang your white pelf: sure, Sir, by your largess you mistake me for Martin Parker, the Ballad-Maker; your covetousness has offended my Muse, and quite dull'd her.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: How angry the poor Devil is? in fine thou art as chollerick as a Cook by a Fire-side.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: I am over-heated, like a Gun, with continual discharging my wit: 'slife, Sir, I have rarifi'd my brains for you, till they are evaporated; but come, Sir, do something for your self like a man, I have engag'd you shall give to your Mistress a Serenade in your proper person: I'll borrow a Lute for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I'll warrant thee I'll do't man.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: You never learn't, I do not think you know one stop.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter for that, Sir, I'll play as fast as I can, and never stop at all.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Go to, you are an invincible Fool I see; get up into your Window, and set two Candles by you, take my Land-lords Lute in your hand, and fumble on't, and make grimmaces with your mouth, as if you sung; in the mean time. I'll play in the next Room in the dark, and consequently your Mistress, who will come to her Balcone over against you, will think it to be you; and at the end of every Tune, I'll ring the Bell that hangs between your Chamber and mine, that you may know when to have done.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Why, this is fair Play now, to tell a man before-hand what he must do; Gramercy i'faith, Boy, now if I fail thee—

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: About your business then, your Mistress and her Maid appear already: I'll give you the sign with the Bell when I am prepar'd, for my Lute is at hand in the Barbers Shop.
sp.stage: Enter Millisent, Rose, with a Candle by 'em above.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: We shall have rare Musick.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: I wish it prove so; for I suspect the Knight can neither p'ay nor sing.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: But if he does, you're bound to pay the Musick, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: I'll not believe it, except both my Ears and Eyes are Witnesses.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: But 'tis night, Madam, and you cannot see'em; yet he may play admirably in the dark.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Where's my Father?

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: You need not fear him, he's still employ'd with that same Sea-man, and I have set Mrs. Christian to watch their discourse, that betwixt her and me Warner may have wherewithal to instruct his Master.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: But yet there's fear my Father will find out the Plot.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Not in the least, for my old Lady has provided two rare disguises for the Master and the Man.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Peace, I hear them beginning to tune the Lute.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: And see, Madam, where your true Knight Sir Martin is plac'd yonder like Apollo, with his Lute in his hand and his Rays about his head.
sp.stage: Sir Martin appears at the adverse Window, a Tune play'd; when it is done, Warner rings, and Sir Martin holds.
sp.p: Did he not play most excellently, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: He play'd well, and yet methinks he held his Lute but untowardly.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p:
Dear Madam, peace; now for the Song.
The SONG.
BLind Love to this hour
Had never like me, a Slave under his power.
Then blest be the Dart
That he threw at my heart,
For nothing can prove
A joy so great as to be wounded with love.
My Days and my Nights
Are fill'd to the purpose with sorrows and frights;
From my heart still I sigh
And my Eyes are ne'r dry,
So that Cupid be prais'd,
I am to the top of Love's happiness rais'd.
My Soul's all on fire.
So that I have the pleasure to doat and desire,
Such a pretty soft pain
That it tickles each vein,
'Tis the dream of a smart,
Which makes me breathe short when it beats at my heart:
Sometimes in a Pet,
When I am despis'd, I my freedom would get;
But streight a sweet smile
Does my anger beguile,
And my heart does recall,
Then the more I do struggle, the lower I fall.
Heaven does not impart
Such a grace as to love unto ev'ry ones heart;
For many may wish
To be wounded and miss:
Then blest be loves Fire,
And more blest her Eyes that first taught me desire.
sp.stage: The Song being done, Warner rings agen; but Sir Martin continues fumbling, and gazing on his Mist ess.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: A prety humour'd Song— but stay, methinks he plays and sings still, and yet we cannot hear him.— Play louder. Sir Martin, that we may have the fruits on't.

sp.speaker: Warn. peeping.
sp.p: D ath! this abominable Fool will spoil all agen. Dam him, he stands making his Grimaces yonder, and he looks so earnestly upon his Mistress, that he hears me not.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Ah, ah! have I found you out, Sir? now as I live and breathe, this is pleasant, Rose,— his man play'd and sung for him, and he, it seems, did not know when he should give over.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: They have found him out, and laugh yonder as if they would split their sides. Why Mr. Fool, Oaf, Coxcomb, will you hear none of your names?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Sir Martin, Sir Martin, take your Mans counsel, and keep time with your Musick.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart. peeping.
sp.p: Hah! what do you say. Madam? how does your Ladiship like my Musick?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: O most heavenly! just like the Harmony of the Spheres that is to be admired, and never heard.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: You have ruin'd all by your not leaving off in time.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: What the Devil would you have a man do when my hand is in! well o'my conscience I think there is a fate upon me.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Look, Rose, what's the matter.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: 'Tis Sir John Swallow pursu'd by the Bailiffs, Madam, according to our Plot; it seems they have dogg'd him thus late to his Lodging.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: That's well! for though I begin not to love this Fool; yet I am glad I shall be rid on him.
sp.stage: Enter Sir John pursu'd by three Bailiffs over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p:
Now I'll redeem all agen, my Mistress shall see my Va our, I m resolv'd on't, Villains, Rogues, Poultroons! what?
three upon one? in fine, I'll be with you immediately.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Why, Sir, are you stark mad? have you no grain of sense left? he's gone! now is he as earnest in the quarrel as Cokes among the Puppets; 'tis to no purpose whatever I do for him.
sp.stage: Enter Sir John and Sir Martin (having driven away the Bailiffs) Sir Martin flourisheth his Sword,

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Victoria! Victoria! what heart, Sir John, you have received no harm, I hope?

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: Not the least, I thank you Sir for your timely assistance, which I will requite with any thing but the resigning of my Mrs— Dear Sir Martin, a good night.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Pray let me wait upon you in Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I can find my way to Mrs. Millcsent without you, Sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: But pray, what were you to be arrested for?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I know no more than you; some little debts perhaps I left unpaid by my negligence: once more good night, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: He's an ungrateful Fellow; and so in fine, I shall tell him when I see him next— Monsieur—
Warner, A propos! I hope you'l applaud me now, I have defeated the Enemy, and that in sight of my Mistress; Boy, I have charm'd her i'faith with my Valour.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: I, just as much as you did e'n now with your Musick; go, you are so beastly a fool, that a Chiding is thrown away upon you.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Fool in your face, Sir; call a man of Honour, Fool, when I have just atchieved such an Enterprise— Gad now my blood's up, I am a dangerous person, I can tell you that, Warner.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Poor Animal, I pity thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I grant I am no Musician, but you must allow me for a Sword-man, I have beat 'em bravely; and in fine, I am come off unhurt, save only a little scratch i'th'head.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p:
That's impossible, thou hast a Scull so thick, no Sword can pierce it; but much good may 't d'ye, Sir, with the fruits of
your Valour: you rescu'd your Rival when he was to be arrested on purpose to take him off from your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Why, this is ever the Fate of ingenuous men; nothing thrives they take in hand.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Sir Martin, you have done your business with my Lady, she'l never look upon you more; she says, she's so well satisfied of your Wit and Courage, that she will not put you to any further tryal.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Warner, is there no hopes, Warner?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: None that I know.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Let's have but one civil Plot more before we part.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: 'Tis to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Yet if he had some golden Friends that would engage for him the next time—

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Here's a Jacobus and a Carolus will enter into Bonds for me.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: I'll take their Royal words for once.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: The meaning of this, Dear Rose.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: 'Tis in pursuance of thy own invention, Warner; a child which thy wit hath begot upon me: but let us lose no time, Help! help! dress thy Master, that he may be Anthony, old Moody's Bastard, and thou his, come from the East-Indies.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Hey-tarock it— now we shall have Roses device too, I long to be at it, pray let's hear more on't.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Old Moody you must know in his younger years, when he was a Cambridge-Scholar, made bold with a Towns-mans Daughter there, by whom he had a Bastard whose name was Anthony, whom you Sir Martin, are to represent.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I warrant you, let me alone for Tony: but pray go on, Rose.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: This Child in his Fathers time he durst not own, but bred him privately in the Isle of Ely, till he was seven years old, and from thence sent him with one Bonaventure a Merchant for the East-Indies:

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: But will not this over-burden your memory, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: There's no answering thee any thing, thou think'st I am good for nothing.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p:
Bonaventure dy'd at Surat within two years, and this Anthony
has liv'd up and down in the Moguls Country unheard of by his Father till this night, and is expected within these three days: now if you can pass for him, you may have admittance into the house, and make an end of all the business before the other Anthony arrives.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: But hold, Rose, there's one considerable point omitted; what was his Mother's name?

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: That indeed I had forgot; her name was Dorothy, Daughter to one Draw-water a Vintner at the Rose.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Come, Sir, are you perfect in your Lesson? Anthony Moody born in Cambridge, bred in the Isle of Ely, sent into the Moguls Country at seven years old with one Bonaventure a Merchant, who dyed within two years; your Mothers name Dorothy Draw-water, the Vintners Daughter at the Rose.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I have it all ad unguem— what do'st think I'm a Sot? but stay a little, how have I liv'd all this while in that same Country?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: What Country?— Pox, he has forgot already—

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: The Moguls Country.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I, I, the Moguls Country! what the Devil, any man may mistake a little; but now I have it perfect: but what have I been doing all this while in the Moguls Country? He's a Heathen Rogue, I am afraid I shall never hit upon his name.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Why, you have been passing your time there, no matter how.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Well, if this passes upon the Old man, I'll bring your business about agen with my Mistress, never fear it; stay you here at the door, I'll go tell the Old man of your arrival.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Well, Sir, now play your part exactly, and I'll forgive all your former errors.—

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Hang'em, they were only slips of Youth— how peremptory and domineering this Rogue is! now he see's I have need of his service: would I were out of his power agen, I would make him lye at my feet like any Spaniel.
sp.stage: Enter Moody, Sir John, Lord, Lady Dupe, Millisent, Christian, Rose.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: Is he here already, say'st thou? which is he?

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: That Sun-burn'd Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: My dear Boy Anthony, do I see thee agen before I dye? welcome, welcome.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: My dear Father, I know it is you by instinct; for methinks I am as like you as if I were spit out of your mouth.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Keep it up I beseech your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: He's wond'rous like indeed.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: The very image of him.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: Anthony, you must salute all this Company: this is my Lord Dartmouth, this my Lady Dupe, this her Niece Mrs. Christian.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: And that's my Sister, methinks I have a good resemblance of her too: honest Sister, I must need kiss you Sister.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: This fool will discover himself, I foresee it already by his carriage to her.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: And now Anthony, pray tell's a little of your Travels.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Time enough for that, forsooth Father, but I have such a natural affection for my Sister, that methinks I could live and dye with her: give me thy hand sweet Sister.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: She's beholding to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: What if she be Sir, what's that to you Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, I have not offended you?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: It may be you have, and it may be you have not, Sir; you see I have no mind to satisfie you, Sir: what a Devil! a man cannot talk a little to his own flesh and blood, but you must be interposing with a murrain to you.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: Enough of this, good Anthony, this Gentleman is to marry your Sister.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: He marry my Sister: ods foot, Sir, there are some Bastards, that shall be nameless, that are as well worthy to marry her, as any man; and have as good blood in their veins.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I do not question it in the least, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p:
'Tis not your best course, Sir; you marry my Sister!
what have you seen of the world, Sir? I have seen your Hurricanos, and your Calentures, and your Eclipticks, and your Tropick Lines, Sir, an'you go to that, Sir.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: You must excuse my Master, the Sea's a little working in his brain, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: And your Prester Johns o'th' East-Indies, and your Great Turk of Rome and Persia,

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: Lord, what a thing it is to be Learned, and a Traveller! Bodikins it makes me weep for joy; but, Anthony, you must not bear your self too much upon your Learning, Child.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Pray Brother be civil to this Gentleman for my sake.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: For your sake, Sister Millisent, much may be done, and here I kiss your hand on't.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Yet again stupidity?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Nay, pray Brother hands off, now you are too rude.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Dear Sister, as I am a true East-India Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: But pray Son Anthony, let us talk of other matters and tell me truly, had you not quite forgot me? and yet I made woundy much of you when you were young.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I remember you as well as if I saw you but yesterday: A fine grey-headed— grey-bearded old Gentleman as ever I saw in all my life.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Grey-bearded old Gentleman! when he was a Scholar at Cambridge.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: But do you remember where you were bred up?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: O yes, Sir, most perfectly, in the Isle— stay— let me see, oh— now I have it— in the Isle of Silly.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: In the Isle of Ely, sure you mean?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Without doubt he did, Sir, but this dam'd Isle of Silly runs in's head ever since his Sea-Voyage.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: And your Mothers name was— come pray let me examine you— for that I'm sure you cannot forget.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Warner! what was it Warner?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Poor Mrs. Dorothy Draw water, if she were now alive, what a joyful day would this be to her?

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: Who the Devil bid you speak, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Her name, Sir, was Mrs. Dorothy Draw-water.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I'll be hang'd if this be not some Cheat.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: He makes so many stumbles, he must needs fall at last.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: But you remember I hope where you were born?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Well, they may talk what they will of Oxford for an Vniversity, but Cambridge for my money.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: Hold your tongue you Scanderbag Rogue you, this is the second time you have been talking when you should not.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I was born at Cambridge, I remember it as perfectly as if it were but yesterday.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: How I sweat for him! he's remembring ever since he was born.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: And who did you go over with to the East-Indies?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Warner!

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: 'T was a happy thing, Sir, you lighted upon so honest a Merchant as Mr. Bonaventure, to take care of him.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: Sawcy Rascal! this is past all sufferance.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: We are undone Warner, if this discourse go on any further.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, take pity o'th' poor Gentleman, he has more need of a good Supper, than to be ask'd so many Questions.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: These are Rogues, Sir, I plainly perceive it; pray let me ask him one question— which way did you come home, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: We came home by Land, Sir.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: That is, from India to Persia, from Persia to Turky, from Turky to Germany, from Germany to France.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And from thence, over the narrow Seas on Horseback.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: 'Tis so, I discern it now, but some shall smoke for't. Stay a little Anthony, I'll be with you presently.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: That wicked old man is gone for no good, I'm afraid, would I were fairly quit of him.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Tell me no more of Sir Martin, Rose, he wants natural sence, to talk after this rate; but for this Warner, I am strangely taken with him, how handsomely he brought him off?

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: Among half a score tough Cudgels I had in my Chamber, I have made choice of these two as best able to hold out.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Alas! poor Warner must be beaten now for all his wit, would I could bear it for him.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: But to what end is all this preparation, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: In the first place, for your Worship, and in the next, for this East-India Apostle, that will needs be my Son Anthony.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Why d'ye think he is not?

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: No, thou wicked Accomplice in his designs, I know he is not

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Who, I his Accomplice? I beseech you, Sir, what is it to me, if he should prove a Counterfeit; I assure you he has cozen'd me in the first place.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: That's likely, i'faith, cozen his own Servant?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: As I hope for mercy, Sir, I am an utter stranger to him, he took me up but yesterday, and told me the story word for word as he told it you.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: What will become of us two now? I trust to the Rogues wit to bring me off.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: If thou woud'st have me believe thee, take one of these two Cudgels, and help me to lay it on soundly.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: Out you Cheat, you Hypocrite, you Imposter! do you come hither to cozen an honest man?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Do you come hither with a lye to get a Father, Mr. Anthony of East-India?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Hold you inhumane Butcher.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: I'll teach you to counterfeit again, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: The Rogue will murder me.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: A fair riddance of 'em both: let's in and laugh at 'em
sp.stage: Enter again Sir Martin, and Warner.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Was there ever such an affront put upon a man, to be beaten by his Servant?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: After my hearty salutations upon your back-side, Sir, may a man have leave to ask you, what news from the Moguls Country?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I wonder where thou hadst the impudence to move such a question to me, knowing how thou hast us'd me.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Now, Sir, you may see what comes of your indiscretion and stupidity: I alwayes gave you warning of it, but for this time I am content to pass it by without more words, partly, because I have already corrected you, though not so much as you deserve.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Do'st thou think to carry it off at this rate, after such an injury?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: You may thank your self for't; nay 'twas very well I found out that way, otherwise I had been suspected as your Accomplice.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: But you laid it on with such a vengeance, as if you were bearing of a Stock-fish.

sp.speaker: VVarn.
sp.p: To confess the truth on't, you had anger'd me, and I was willing to evaporate my choler; if you will pass it by so, I may chance to help you to your Mistress: no more words of this business, I advise you, but go home and grease your back.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: In fine, I must suffer it at his hands; for if my shoulders had not paid for this fault, my purse must have sweat blood for't: the Rogue has got such a hank upon me—

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: So, so, here's another of our Vessels come [Enter Rose. in after the storm that parted us: what comfort, Rose, no Harbour near?

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: My Lady, as you may well imagine, is most extreamly incens'd against Sir Martin; but she applauds your ingenuity to the Skies. I'll say no more, but thereby hangs a Tale.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I am considering with my self about a Plot, to bring all about agen.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Yet again plotting! if you have such a mind to't, I know no way so proper for you as to turn Poet to Pugenello.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Hark! is not that Musick in your house?

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Yes Sir John has given my Mistress the Fiddles, and our Old-man is as jocund yonder, and does so hug himself to think how he has been reveng'd upon you.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Why, he does not know 'twas we, I hope?

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: 'Tis all one for that.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p:
I have such a Plot; I care not, I will speak an'I were
to be hang'd for't— shall I speak, dear Warner? let me now, it does so wamble within me, just like a Clyster, i'faith law, and I can keep it no longer for my heart.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Well, I am indulgent to you; out with it boldly in the name of Non-sense.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: We two will put on Vizards, and with the help of my Lordland, who shall be of the party, go a Mumming there, and by some device of dancing, get my Mistress away unsuspected by 'em all.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: What if this should hit now, when all your projects have fail'd, Warner?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Would I were hang'd if it be not somewhat probable: nay, now I consider better on't— exceeding probable, it must take, 'tis not in Nature to be avoided.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: O must it so, Sir! and who may you thank for't?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Now am I so mad he should be the Author of this device. How the Devil, Sir, came you to stumble on't?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Why should not my brains be as fruitful as yours or any mans?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: This is so good, it shall not be your Plot, Sir, either disown it, or I will proceed no further.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I would not lose the credit of my Plot to gain my Mistress: the Plot's a good one, and I'll justifie it upon any ground of England; an'you will not work upon't, it shall be done without you.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: I think the Knight has reason.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Well, I'll order it however to the best advantage: hark you, Rose.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: If it miscarry by your ordering, take notice 'tis your fault, 'tis well invented I'll take my Oath on't.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: I must in to 'em, for fear I should be suspected; but I'll acquaint my Lord, my old Lady, and all the rest who ought to know it, with your design.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: We'll be with you in a twinkling: you and I, Rose, are to follow our Leaders, and be pair'd to night—

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: To have, and to hold, are dreadful words, Warner; but for your sake I'll venture on 'em.
sp.stage: Enter Lord, Lady Dupe, and Christian.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: Nay! good my Lord be patient.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Does he think to give Fiddles and Treatments in a house where he has wrong'd a Lady? I'll never suffer it.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: But upon what ground will you raise your quarrel?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: A very just one, as I am her Kinsman.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: He does not know yet why he was to be arrested; try that way agen.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I'll hear of nothing but revenge.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Yes, pray hear me one word, my Lord, Sir Martin himself has made a Plot.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: That's like to be a good one.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: A Fool's Plot may be as lucky as a Fools's Handsel; 'tis a very likely one, and requires nothing for your part, but to get a Parson in the next room, we'll find work for him.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: That shall be done immediately; Christian, make haste, and send for Mr. Ball the Non-conformist, tell him here are two or three Angels to be earn'd.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: And two or three Possets to be eaten: may I not put in that, Madam?

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: Surely you may.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Then for the rest— 'tis only this— Oh! they are here! pray take it in a whisper: my Lady knows of it already.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Strike up agen, Fiddle, I'll have a French Dance.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Let's have the Brawls.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: No, good Sir John, no quarrelling among Friends.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: Your Company is like to be increas'd, Sir; some Neighbours that heard your Fiddles are come a mumming to you.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: Let 'em come in, and we'l be Jovy; an' I had but my Hobby-horse at home——

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What, are they Men or Women?

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: I believe some Prentices broke loose.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Rose! go and fetch me down two Indian gowns and Vizard-masks— you and I will disguise too, and be as good a Mummery to them as they to us.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: That will be most rare.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Martin, Warner; Landlord disguised like a Tony.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: O here they come! Gentlemen Maskers you are welcome— He signs for a Dance I believe; you are welcome, Mr. Musick, strike up, I'll make one as old as I am.
sp.stage: [Warner signs to the Musick for a Dance.]

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And I'll not be out.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Gentlemen Maskers, you have had the Frolick, the next turn is mine; bring two Flute-glasses and some stools, Ho, we'll have the Ladies health.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But why stools, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: That you shall see: the humour is, that two men at a time are hoysted up; when they are above, they name their Ladies, and the rest of the Company dance about them while they drink: this they call the Frolick of the Altitudes.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: Some High-lander's invention, I'll warrant it.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Gentlemen-maskers, you shall begin.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Name the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: They point to Mrs. Millisent and Mrs. Christian, A Lou's Touche! Touche!

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: A rare toping health this: come Sir John, now you and I will be in our altitudes.
sp.stage: While they drink the Company dances) and sings: they are taken down.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What new device is this tro?

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: I know not what to make on't.

sp.speaker: Sir John to Tony.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Fool, where's the rest o'your Company? I would fain see 'em again.
sp.stage: When they are up, the Company dances about 'em: then dance off. Tony dances a fig.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Come down and tell 'em so, Cudden:

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I'll be hang'd if there be not some Plot in't, and this Fool is set here to spin out the time.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: Like enough! undone! undone! my Daughters's gone, let me down, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Yes, Cudden.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: My Mistress is gone, let me down first.
sp.stage: (He offers to pull down the stools.)

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: This is the quickest way, Cudden.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Hold! hold! or thou wilt break my neck.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: And you will not come down, you may stay there, Cudden.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: O Scanderbag Villains!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Is there no getting down?

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: All this was long of you Sir Jack.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: 'Twas long of your self to invite them hither.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: O you young Coxcombs, to be drawn in thus!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: You old Sot you, to be caught so sillily!

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: Come but an inch nearer, and I'll so claw thee.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I hope I shall reach to thee.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: And 'twere not for thy wooden breast-work there.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I hope to push thee down from Babylon.
sp.stage: Enter Lord, Lady Dupe, Sir Martin, Warner, Rose, Millisent vail'd, Landlord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: How, Gentlemen! what quarrelling among your selves!

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: Coxnowns! help me down, and let me have fair play, he shall never marry my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart. leading Rose.
sp.p: No I'll be sworn that he shall not, therefore never repine, Sir, for Marriages you know are made in Heaven: in fine, Sir, we are joyn'd together in spig't of Fortune.

sp.speaker: Rose pulling off her mask.
sp.p: That we are indeed, Sir Martin, and these are Witnesses; therefore in fine never repine, Sir, for Marriages you know are made in Heaven.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Rose!

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: What, is Rose split in two? sure I ha' got one Rose!

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: I, the best Rose you ever got in all your life.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: This amazeth me so much, I know not what to say or think.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: My Daughter married to Warner!

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p:
Well, I thought it impossible any man in England
should have over reach'd me: sure Warner there was some mistake in this: prithee Billy let's go to the Parson to set all right again, that every man may have his own before the matter go 100 far.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Well, Sir! for my part I will have nothing farther to do with these Women, for I find they will be too hard for us, but e'n sit down by the loss, and content my self with my hard fortune: But, Madam, do you ever think I will forgive you this, to cheat me into an Estate of 2000 l. a year?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: And I were as thee, I would not be so serv'd Warner!

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: I have serv'd him but right for the cheat he put upon me, when he perswaded me you were a Wit— now there's a trick for your trick, Sir.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Nay, I confess you have out-witted me.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Let me down, and I'll forgive all freely.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: What am I kept here for?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: I might in policy keep you there, till your Daughter and I had been in private, for a little consummation: But for once, Sir, I'll trust your good nature.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: And thou wert a Gentleman it would not grieve me!

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: That I was assur'd of before I married him, by my Lord here.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I cannot refuse to own him for my Kinsman, though his Father's sufferings in the late times hath ruin'd his Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: But yet he has been a Serving-man.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: You are mistaken, Sir, I have been a Master, and besides there's an Estate of 800 l. a year, only it is mortgaged for 6000 l.

sp.speaker: Mood.
sp.p: Well, we'll bring it off, and for my part, I am glad my Daughter has miss'd in fine, there.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I will not be the only man that must sleep without a Bedfellow to night, if this Lady will once again receive me.

sp.speaker: La. Dupe.
sp.p: She's yours, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: And the sam Parson, that did the former execution, is still in the next Chamber; what with Cawdels Wine, and Quidding, which he has taken in abundance, I think he will be able to wheadle two more of you into matrimony.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Poor Sir Martin looks melancholly! I am half afraid he is in love.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Not with the Lady that took him for a Wit, I hope.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: At least, Sir Martin can do more than you Mr. Warner, for he can make me a Lady, which you cannot my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: I have lost nothing but my Man, and in fine, I shall get another.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: You'll do very well, Sir Martin, for you'll never be your own Man, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: For my part I had lov'd you before if I had follow'd my inclination.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: But now I am afraid you begin of the latest, except your love can grow up like a Mushrome at a nights warning.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: For that matter never trouble your self, I can love as fast as any man, when I am nigh possession; my love falls heavy, and never moves quick till it comes near the Centre; he's an ill Falconer that will unhood before the quarry be in sight.
Love's an high mettal'd Hawk that beats the Air,
But soon grows weary when the Game's not near.

lg.l: AS Country Vicars, when the Sermon's done,
Run hudling to the Benediction;
Well knowing, though the better sort may stay,
The Vulgar Rout will run unblest away:
So we, when once our Play is done, make haste
With a short Epilogue to close your taste.
In thus withdrawing we seem mannerly,
But when the Curtain's, down we peep and see
A Jury of the Wits who still stay late,
And in their Club decree the poor Plays fate;
Their Verdict back is to the Boxes brought,
Thence all the Town pronounces it their thought.
Thus, Gallants, we like Lilly can foresee,
But if you ask us what our doom will be,
We by to morrow will our Fortune cast,
As he tells all things when the Year is past.
